Teach, study, work out, repeat: Pawlowski serves prison time In first year at low-security facility in Conn., says he keeps busy, stays in shape

Autor: Opilo, Emily. 

Información de publicación: Morning Call ; Allentown, Pa. [Allentown, Pa]. 10 Jan 2020: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/teach-study-work-out-repeat-pawlowski-serves/docview/2334989009/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Teach%2C+study%2C+work+out%2C+repeat%3A+Pawlowski+serves+prison+time+In+first+year+at+low-security+facility+in+Conn.%2C+says+he+keeps+busy%2C+stays+in+shape&amp;author=Opilo%2C+Emily&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Morning+Call&amp;issn=0884-5557&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Spin class. Learning Arabic. Consuming every book in the law library.
This self-improvement regimen isn't part of a New Year's resolution. It's how ex-Allentown Mayor Ed Pawlowski is occupying his time in prison.
Pawlowski, 54, Allentown's mayor for more than a decade, was sentenced to 15 years behind bars in 2018 for a pay-to-play corruption scandal that traded city contracts for campaign donations. He has been serving time at Federal Correctional Institution Danbury, a low-security prison camp in Connecticut, since December 2018, when he was transferred there from a federal holding facility in Philadelphia.
During his first year in prison, Pawlowski said, he has maintained a busy schedule including drumming in several bands, teaching a class on government and studying federal law, according to a letter he wrote to The Morning Call in response to an interview request.
Pawlowski, who has a degree in urban planning and public policy from the University of Illinois, said his civics class includes an overview of the U.S. Constitution, the legislative process and the various branches of government. The curriculum is supplemented with movies and shows including "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" and "Schoolhouse Rock."
When he's not teaching, Pawlowski takes a turn as a student, studying Hebrew, Arabic and Spanish.
"I thought Hebrew would be the hardest to learn, but Arabic is tough, especially since each letter has beginning, middle and ending form," Pawlowski wrote.
The former mayor said he spends his afternoons and weekends in the prison's law library, where he has become "quite the legal scholar." There, Pawlowski said he works on his appeal, which is being considered by the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. And he has also been helping inmates with immigration paperwork and presidential pardon requests.
"I'm thinking of just skipping law school and just taking the bar exam when I get out," he wrote, punctuating the sentence with "(smile)."
Pawlowski is due to be released in 2031.
Asked to corroborate the details of Pawlowski's letter, the executive assistant at FCI Danbury said the prison cannot release information on an individual inmate's education and activities.
"However, the Bureau of Prison provides a wide variety of educational, vocational, and recreation activities to the inmate population to participate in which provide opportunities for skill enhancement to prepare for reentry and encourages inmates to use their time constructively," prison officials said in a statement.
The ex-mayor said he also is using his time to get in shape and that he's dropped 30 pounds. He enrolled in yoga and spin classes, walks the track each morning and works out in the weight room three times a week.
"The one good thing about prison is that it has gotten me in shape," he said.
Also a graduate of Moody Bible Institute in Chicago, Pawlowski has drawn upon his religious background, acting as a head elder for the prison's church. He said he leads a Bible study once a week and collects donations from inmates of soup, toothpaste and toothbrushes for new inmates. He has also been drumming in a worship band as well as in a blues/rock group. Pawlowski said his drumming occupies about 10 hours each week.
Church elder isn't the only leadership role he's held. Pawlowski said he is also "administrative orderly" for his 80-inmate unit, overseeing a crew of 15 men who clean it, securing supplies and handling quality of life issues.
"It's kind of like being mayor but for a lot less money," Pawlowski wrote. "I get all the complaints, work the bureaucracy to get things done and attempt to motivate folks to keep our living environment habitable."
For those eager to hear more about Pawlowski's stint in prison, he said he has begun writing a book about the experience. FCI Danbury was also the inspiration for the memoir "Orange is the New Black," penned by Piper Kerman.
"I'm sure it will be on The New York Times best seller list soon (smile)," Pawlowski wrote.
Morning Call reporter Emily Opilo can be reached at eopilo@mcall.com or 610-820-6522.

Former Allentown Mayor Ed Pawlowski and his wife, Lisa, leave the Edward Cahn U.S. Courthouse after he was convicted March 1.
Morning Call File Photo

'Vagina Monologues' coming to ArtsQuest Center in Bethlehem

Autor: Moser, John J. 

Información de publicación: Morning Call ; Allentown, Pa. [Allentown, Pa]. 10 Jan 2020: A.6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/vagina-monologues-coming-artsquest-center/docview/2334988892/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=%27Vagina+Monologues%27+coming+to+ArtsQuest+Center+in+Bethlehem&amp;author=Moser%2C+John+J&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Morning+Call&amp;issn=0884-5557&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: "The Vagina Monologues," a play about female sexuality, body image and other topics from the viewpoint of a variety of women, is coming to ArtsQuest Center in Bethlehem.
The episodic play, which features women frankly talking about their relationship to their anatomy, including childbirth, pelvic exams, rape and orgasms, will be performed at 6 p.m. Feb. 16, Valentine's Day weekend, in the Blast Furnace Room.
Tickets, at $22.50 for Arts-Quest members, $23 for students and seniors and $25 for others, are on sale at the ArtsQuest Center box office, at www.steelstacks.org and at 610-332-3378.
All proceeds from the play will be donated to Women's Resources of Monroe County and Crime Victims Council of the Lehigh Valley.
The humorous play, which started as an off-off-Broadway production in 1996, won author Eve Ensler the Off-Broadway Obie Award for Best New Play that year and has been called by The New York Times "probably the most important piece of political theater of the last decade,"
At ArtsQuest Center, the play will be produced by Samuel Saint Thomas, a Bethlehem professor and musician, and directed by Casey McGinty, a Lehigh Valley actress and musician.
"There has never been a more important and crucial time than now to bring men into the conversation of women's empowerment and freedom," Saint Thomas said.
"The Vagina Monologues," first performed in a cafe basement in New York's Greenwich Village, has been translated into 48 languages and performed in more than 140 countries.
Morning Call Lehigh Valley Music reporter and columnist John J. Moser can be reached at 610-820-6722 orjmoser@mcall.com

More attention needed on human cost of marijuana

Autor: O'Donnell, Jayne. 

Información de publicación: The Advocate ; Newark, Ohio [Newark, Ohio]. 10 Jan 2020: A.7.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/more-attention-needed-on-human-cost-marijuana/docview/2334987221/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=More+attention+needed+on+human+cost+of+marijuana&amp;author=O%27Donnell%2C+Jayne&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Advocate&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: I've covered things that injure, sicken and kill kids and adults for more than 30 years. From auto safety to medical errors, I've competed to break stories on the latest deadly defect or health policy change, most recently on electronic cigarettes.
In late August, I added vaping-related lung illnesses to the beat. Last month, I added marijuana, psychosis and other mental illnesses.
A search on the news archive Nexis shows that the number of stories mentioning "vaping" and "lung illness" went from 953 in September to 584 in October, a nearly 40% drop.
The deaths and injuries from lung illnesses are declining, but they've hardly abated and are clearly a sign of a much larger problem with excessive marijuana use among young people. Yet families from the D'Ambrosios in California to the Donats in Connecticut were caught unaware.
Ricky D'Ambrosio, 21, was in a medically induced coma for four of the 10 days he was hospitalized in August after vaping THC from a dispensary. He had a medical marijuana card.
D'Ambrosio's recovering well now, but my Connecticut high school friend Billy Donat's family wasn't so lucky.
Recently, Donat emailed me for the first time: "Sometimes we reach out to old friends at the worst of times, this is one of those times. On Christmas Day, my son of 22 years put an electric cord around his neck and hung himself one day after his release from Yale Psychiatric Hospital. On the table in the living room was a copy (of) USA Today dated 12/16/2019. I told my son that you had written an article about his condition linking pot to psychosis. SCHIZOPHRENIA. I had read the front page at the news stand. I wish I had turned to page 6 and finished the article."
If he had, he would have seen that the federal "mental health czar" and psychiatrist, Elinore McCance-Katz, lamenting about how little attention the "settled science" on pot and psychosis gets and the huge increase in suicides among young people with marijuana in their systems in Colorado.
On Tuesday, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said 2,561 people have been hospitalized with vaping-related lung illness and 55 have died. That's one more death and over 50 more hospitalizations from two weeks earlier. CDC said 80% of hospitalized patients who had complete information about their products reported vaping THC; 13% said they vaped just nicotine.
Former New York Times business reporter Alex Berenson says that the human cost of cannabis is too high – and that the media is too pro-pot. When his latest book, "Tell Your Children: The Truth about Marijuana, Mental Illness and Violence," came out last year, he knew marijuana proponents wouldn't like it. He just didn't think there would be what he calls a "media brownout": No publications reviewed it. (USA TODAY interviewed him for a March article.)
The recent story I wrote with colleagues on marijuana's link to mental health ran on the front page and was one of the top stories on our website for days. More than 250 people with children or personal experience with mental illness linked to marijuana joined our Facebook support group – I Survived It.
I don't know about you, but that makes me pay attention.
Jayne O'Donnell covers health policy for USA TODAY.

Film's legend links Eisenhower, extraterrestrials

Autor: Archer, Greg. 

Información de publicación: The Desert Sun ; Palm Springs, Calif. [Palm Springs, Calif]. 10 Jan 2020: D.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/films-legend-links-eisenhower-extraterrestrials/docview/2334983597/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Film%27s+legend+links+Eisenhower%2C+extraterrestrials&amp;author=Archer%2C+Greg&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.3&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Desert+Sun&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: Written and directed by Christopher Munch, "The 11th Green" begins on slow simmer and eventually arrives at an emotional boil as it floats back and forth through time to explore a curious proposition: that former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was not only interested in but also had contact with extraterrestrials.
The film, which was partially shot in Palm Desert and other Coachella Valley locations, screens in the Locals Spotlight program at the 31st annual Palm Springs International Film Festival.
"There was an urban legend out there for some time, and I believe reports first appeared in the 1950s that Dwight Eisenhower had one or more face-to-face interactions with visitors from other worlds," Munch says. "What interested me about the story was not so much the specifics of it or whether it was true or not, but more so the emotional 'what if?' involving Eisenhower. How this man would have potentially reflected back on those experiences late in his life. Would he have regrets or done things differently?"
How did Munch craft a story with a potentially contentious subject matter that today's audiences could embrace? With an inventive storyline.
The plot: After his 85-year-old father dies from a sudden heart attack, slick Washington D.C. journalist Jeremy Rudd (played by Campbell Scott) returns to his golf resort home. Fighting memories of his beleaguered father-and-son relationship, Jeremy suddenly becomes much more acquainted with his father's mysterious legacy.
Toss in a romantic interest via his father's former assistant, Laurie (played by Agnes Bruckner), and a visit from his father's protégé, Jacobsen (played by Currie Graham), who hands Jeremy reels of film that suggest America had interaction with off-world visitors 50 years ago, and our protagonist suddenly finds himself in a personal and professional conundrum.
Is his newfound potential love interest clouding his interest? Should he believe in the film footage presented to him?
Running parallel to the present-day storyline, the story reveals Jeremy's father served on the National Security Council staff of the former president (played by George Gerdes) and that the country's collective fear pretty much left the "extraterrestrial question" in the wrong hands. Then, in 1967, two years before his death, the president finds himself revisiting the ghosts of his past in the same house that Jeremy would later inherit from his father, who, in this creative iteration, happened to own it after Ike.
"Originally the storyline was to focus just on Eisenhower in his home in Palm Desert," Munch says. "But ultimately it would take place in several different time periods. I adopted the framing device of a contemporary journalist whose father was a young man in Eisenhower's council and very trusted and I took the liberty of having him purchase the house Eisenhower once lived in, which, of course, didn't happen in real life, but it seemed like a way that the protagonist could get immersed into what happened."
Munch, a Los Angeles resident who frequents the valley, filmed the project on a low budget and with minimal crew. He says he found the Greater Palm Springs Film Alliance & Film Office to be very helpful, noting, "it's exactly the opposite of when you're filming a major production in places like Los Angeles where there's a lot of red tape."
Local landmarks such as Shields Date Garden in Indio, which Munch had visited many times, are also featured in the film.
"I wrote a scene that would take place there in the Shields' theater, where our intelligence operative shows our protagonist the alleged footage from Eisenhower's meeting with the extraterrestrial," he says. "It was nice way to photograph these historic local places."
As for the subject matter of the film, there could be a bit of kismet involved.
A 2017 Washington Post article noted that The Pentagon officially confirmed there was a $22 million government program "to collect and analyze 'anomalous aerospace threats' — government-speak for UFOs." In 2019, the New York Times featured interviews with several Navy pilots who said they witnessed, and in several instances recorded, unexplained flying objects off of the East Coast.
"In the course of the last year, the film has become timelier," Munch says. "Major publications have documented, in a very dry and matter-of-fact way, incidents involving the U.S. Military engaging with UFOs over the past 15 years or so. This has all been presented in a way which cannot be easily dismissed, as it was from the 1950s onward, where UFOs and ETs were only considered in the context of the 'giggle factor.' The subject is timelier even though these current articles have no direct relation to those Eisenhower years."
And what of Eisenhower's alleged encounters with a higher intelligence?
"I find that it would have been very routine for him; I don't think anything really phased Eisenhower," Munch muses.
"As far as my protagonist in the film, I certainly arrived at the scenes with his incredulity. He's a journalist who's reported on mainstream and fringe science. He certainly has a predisposition, but it's balanced out by his concern for the validity of what he's reporting. I think that's the quandary for any journalist who is having to report on the subject of UFOs or extraterrestrials."
If you go
What: "The 11th Green"
When: 9 p.m., Jan. 10
Where: Regal Cinemas, 789 E. Tahquitz Canyon Way, Palm Springs
CREDIT: Greg Archer

County unsure of role in FBI probe

Información de publicación: Des Moines Register ; Des Moines, Iowa [Des Moines, Iowa]. 10 Jan 2020: A.8.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/county-unsure-role-fbi-probe/docview/2334983094/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=County+unsure+of+role+in+FBI+probe&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Des+Moines+Register&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anorthcentralnews_

Texto completo: Polk County became one Esposito's biggest clients, paying $5,000 a month for representation in Washington.
It's unclear what, if any, role Polk County will play in an investigation of a former Washington lobbyist whose home the FBI raided last week.
Polk County Administrator Mark Wandro said this week that county officials have not been contacted by the FBI. And spokespeople for Iowa's congressional delegation said they have heard little about the FBI probe involving Michael Esposito.
Esposito has not returned Des Moines Register phone calls seeking comment, and so far, the FBI has not revealed what it seized in the raid, which the Washington Post reported was seeking evidence of fraud.
The county's link to Esposito and his Federal Advocates lobbying firm goes back more than a decade. It became one his biggest clients, paying $5,000 a month for his representation in Washington.
The relationship took a big leap in 2016. The county signed a new contract with Federal Advocates for $60,000 a month — $720,000 a year — to try to protect the nonprofit status of its Prairie Meadows casino using Esposito's ties in Washington.
Yet the contract, which committed the county to paying more than the nation's largest counties for lobbying services, received little attention until Watchdog reported about it this summer.
"That struck a nerve with me," said state Sen. Claire Celsi, a Des Moines Democrat who blasted the payments on Facebook. "I just knew by looking at those numbers that Polk County had no business trying to justify that amount of spending."
Esposito, meanwhile, was busy signing up other lucrative clients, claiming close ties to President Donald Trump, administration officials and the Republican National Committee. The firm took in $4.76 million last year — before the RNC sent Esposito a cease-and-desist letter and Trump denied on Twitter that he knew the lobbyist.
Now, Esposito is drawing much wider attention following the raid on his suburban Washington home last week by the FBI
Interesting clients Some of Federal Advocates' newer clients are of particular interest to politicians, government watchdogs and reporters.
Esposito registered last year to represent the political party Justice in Ukraine, which is led by Valentyn Nalyvaichenko, a member of parliament and former head of the Ukrainian security services. According to a November article in the Post, Nalyvaichenko called for investigations into Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden and his son, Hunter. Trump's alleged insistence on such an investigation is at the center of the impeachment case against him.
Another client, Huawei Technologies, paid Federal Advocates $1.65 million for three months' work, according to lobbyist filings collected by the Center for Responsive Politics.
The Chinese tech giant has been accused by governments around the world of working with Chinese national spy agencies. The Trump administration had blacklisted the company and its affiliates for doing business with U.S. companies without seeking approval from the U.S. government, and the president told a number of media outlets the U.S. would not be doing business with Huawei because the company was a national security concern.
But in October, the president agreed to issue licenses allowing some American companies to serve as suppliers to Huawei after the ban proved a thorn in U.S.-China trade talks, according to articles in the Wall Street Journal and New York Times.
Public records show that after Trump was elected, Esposito took a sharply different tack with the firm he founded in 2006.
In 2015, Esposito was a lobbyist for Democrats, and tried to use his relationship with the Polk supervisors to drum up business with Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign, emails published by WikiLeaks show.
He wrote Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta, saying he was "extremely close with the supervisors, and the other electeds, who I believe could significantly help early in Iowa."
By last year, Esposito was engaging in riskier practices, like when he hired Hassan Nasser Fawaz, a Lebanese banker with ties to institutions that had been sanctioned by the U.S. Treasury.
According to an investigative report in the Daily Beast, Fawaz's role as senior director of international affairs was to introduce the firm's lobbyists to potential clients who had been sanctioned by the U.S. Treasury Department. His hiring occurred even though it is illegal for American companies to lobby for sanctioned individuals.
The institutions Fawaz worked for had links to Hezbollah and a notorious drug trafficker, according to the report.
After registering as a foreign agent last year, Esposito also hired Alexander Savostianov, a former diplomat who, as deputy consul general of Ukraine in San Francisco, promoted "Ukrainian foreign policy objectives," according to his company biography.
According to the November Post article, Esposito requested meetings last year for a Justice Party official with Vice President Mike Pence, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and then-National Security Adviser John Bolton to discuss the conflict between Ukraine and Russia.
But the meeting requests were denied, he reported.
Generous donor In 2019, Esposito gave at least $30,000 to the Trump Victory political action committee and another $39,100 to the Republican National Committee, according to the Federal Election Commission.
Polk supervisor Matt McCoy said Esposito boasted during a May 2019 conference in Washington that he was very close with Jared Kushner, that he was heading the RNC's re-election efforts for Trump, and that he personally vetted candidates for the Trump cabinet.
"He implied that the guy following us that day was security and was assigned by the Trump team," McCoy said.
In 2018, Esposito made one of the largest campaign donations to Angela Connolly, who headed the county board the year after the supervisors signed their more expensive lobbying contract.
Only millionaire West Des Moines developer Bill Knapp and Kurt Rasmussen, board chairman of Prairie Meadows Racetrack and Casino, gave as much to Connolly's re-election committee that year, according to the Iowa Ethics and Campaign Disclosure Board.
Until Federal Advocates' contract expired in December, Connolly and other supervisors defended the firm and continued to make the monthly $60,000 contract payments after the first Watchdog probe in July.
After Watchdog reports about Federal Advocates, McCoy, who this month became the board's new chairman, voted against further payments. But other supervisors voted in favor of paying the firm's bills until its contract expired in December.
Lee Rood's Reader's Watchdog column helps Iowans get answers and accountability from public officials, the justice system, businesses and nonprofits. Reach her at lrood@dmreg.com or 515-284-8549. Follow her on Twitter at @leerood and on Facebook at Facebook.com/readerswatchdog.

____________________________________________________________

Bulldogs set sail with pirate

Autor: Horka, Tyler. 

Información de publicación: The Clarion Ledger ; Jackson, Miss. [Jackson, Miss]. 10 Jan 2020: A.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bulldogs-set-sail-with-pirate/docview/2334982355/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Bulldogs+set+sail+with+pirate%3A+Mississippi+State+hires+Mike+Leach+to+lead+football+program&amp;author=Horka%2C+Tyler&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.5&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Clarion+Ledger&amp;issn=0744-9526&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: "Mike Leach is a proven winner who has established a culture of excellence for nearly two decades as a head coach, ... he has a track record of building programs to national prominence with accountability and a blue-collar approach. We are thrilled to welcome him and his family to the Mississippi State family."
John Cohen, MSU athletic director
STARKVILLE – The pirate ship has found a new dock.
Washington State head coach Mike Leach, often referred to as "the pirate" because of his fascination with 18th-century pirates, is steering his ship Southeast to become the head coach at Mississippi State.
"I can't tell you how excited I am to be the head football coach of the Mississippi State Bulldogs," Leach said in a statement. "I loved Washington State, but I am excited for the next chapter in the SEC."
Leach has been the head coach at Washington State since 2012. He has compiled a 55-47 record in Pullman. Most recently, the Cougars went 6-7 in 2019 after an 11-2 season in 2018, which marked the most wins in program history.
Leach, 58, replaces Joe Moorhead, who was fired last week after two seasons in Starkville. Moorhead went 14-12 at Mississippi State.
Leach has an overall record of 139-90 in head coaching stops at Texas Tech and Washington State. Leach brought both programs to unprecedented heights. He also led Tech to its only 11-win season in program history in 2008.
"Mike Leach is a proven winner who has established a culture of excellence for nearly two decades as a head coach," MSU athletic director John Cohen said in a statement. "An offensive genius and two-time national coach of the year, he has a track record of building programs to national prominence with accountability and a blue-collar approach. We are thrilled to welcome him and his family to the Mississippi State family and look forward to watching our football program grow under his leadership."
Well known for his air-raid offensive system, Leach has coached some of the best offenses in college football over the last two decades. His quarterback this past season, Anthony Gordon, led the country in passing yards per game.
Gordon threw for 429.2 yards per game. The second man on that list was Heisman Trophy winner Joe Burrow, who passed for 372 yards per game. Gordon also tossed 48 touchdown passes this season, second behind only Burrow's 55.
Washington State had the nation's No. 7 total offense in 2019 despite its losing record. The Cougars racked up 505.2 yards per game.
Time will tell if Leach's pass-heavy offense works in the SEC.
Broyles Award winner Joe Brady, LSU's passing game coordinator who has been credited with revitalizing the Tigers' offensive attack, proved that it probably can, but only if teams have the right pieces.
The ins and outs of whether Leach will work at Mississippi State, though, can and will be discussed once the pirate settles into his new quarters. For now, the Bulldogs are getting a facelift that comes with national exposure.
Leach is known for his comedic antics in press conferences, such as discussing which Pac 12 mascot would win in a melee. He's one of the most recognizable faces and voices in college football.
And that's for better or worse.
Leach was controversially fired from Texas Tech for legal cause in 2009 for an incident involving a player who sustained a concussion on Dec. 16 of that year. The player was Adam James, son of former SMU standout running back Craig James.
According to USA Today Sports, the elder James told then-Texas Tech chancellor Kent Hance in an e-mail that his son was punished by Leach for sustaining the injury and that he was locked in a closet for hours while the rest of the team carried on with daily routines in preparation for the Alamo Bowl, which was to be played two weeks later.
Leach adamantly denied the allegations, but he was suspended by the university on Dec. 28. He was fired on Dec. 30.
Leach's first public comments after his termination came in an interview with the New York Times that was released on Jan. 1, 2010. In the interview, Leach denied that he had mistreated James. He said he ordered James to be taken "out of the light."
"He was never locked anywhere," Leach said. "At no point was he locked anywhere."
Leach also said the James family fabricated the allegations because they were upset about Adam James' lack of playing time. Making matters even messier, Leach said the motive to fire him one year after the best season in program history was monetary.
Leach would have received a $800,000 retention bonus, he told USA Today Sports, if he was still the head coach at Texas Tech on Dec. 31, 2009. He also said he was never given roughly $1.6 million in "guaranteed" income for that season.
Ten years and multiple failed law suits later, Leach does not have the money. But he does have a reputable name in college football again because of his success at Washington State, and he also has a head coaching gig in the SEC as of today.
The pirate ship is still afloat and sailing forward.
"Mike Leach is a proven winner who has established a culture of excellence for nearly two decades as a head coach, ... he has a track record of building programs to national prominence with accountability and a blue-collar approach. We are thrilled to welcome him and his family to the Mississippi State family."
John Cohen, MSU athletic director

5 things to know about coach Leach

Autor: Suss, Nick. 

Información de publicación: The Clarion Ledger ; Jackson, Miss. [Jackson, Miss]. 10 Jan 2020: B.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/5-things-know-about-coach-leach/docview/2334982311/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=5+things+to+know+about+coach+Leach&amp;author=Suss%2C+Nick&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.2&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Clarion+Ledger&amp;issn=0744-9526&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: The Mississippi State football program has announced the hire of Mike Leach, former head coach at Washington State and Texas Tech.
Leach has 18 years of experience as a Power 5 head coach and has led his teams to 16 bowl games. Leach's teams have finished seasons ranked in the top 25 six times, including in 2018 when Washington State went 11-2 and ranked No. 10 in both the AP Top 25 and the Amway Coaches Poll at the end of the season.
Leach is known for being a pioneer of the Air Raid offense and has thrived with quarterbacks putting up eye-popping numbers. He's also known for having a larger-than-life personality in interviews and on Twitter.
Here are five things to know about Mississippi State's new head coach.
1. Mike Leach has a successful track record Leach has a career record of 139-90 in his 18 seasons as a head coach and has led his teams to bowl berths in all but two of those seasons. In 2008, Leach led Texas Tech to an 11-2 record and a Cotton Bowl appearance behind the talents of quarterback Graham Harrell and wide receiver Michael Crabtree.
In 2018, Leach's Washington State Cougars went 11-2 thanks to a record-setting passing season from Mississippi native Gardner Minshew.
Leach has overseen 12 eight-win seasons in his career and has done so in secluded towns like Lubbock, Texas, and Pullman, Washington, that have a reputation for being hard to recruit.
2. Mike Leach loves to throw Leach is a descendant of football legend Hal Mumme's Air Raid passing tree. Leach coached with Mumme at Iowa Wesleyan, Valdosta State and Kentucky, where the pair revolutionized the modern passing offense and thrived with quarterbacks like former No. 1 NFL Draft pick Tim Couch.
Leach continued his pass-first offensive attack for one season as the offensive coordinator at Oklahoma before parlaying those schemes into his head coaching career. Leach's offenses have led the FBS in passing yards per game 10 times in his head coaching career, including each of the last two seasons.
In 2019 alone, Washington State attempted 54.6 pass plays per game. No team finished within 10 pass attempts per game of that mark, with Texas Tech ranking second in the FBS at 44.3 pass plays per game.
3. Mike Leach has a large coaching tree In addition to Leach's success on the field, the coach has done an impressive job of training a generation of offensive minds. Some prominent coaches who have worked under Leach include: SMU coach Sonny Dykes, Houston coach Dana Holgorsen, Oklahoma coach Lincoln Riley, North Texas coach Seth Littrell and former Baylor coach Art Briles.
Leach also coached a large number of players who have become prominent coaches. That list includes: Arizona Cardinals coach Kliff Kingsbury, West Virginia coach Neal Brown, UCF coach Josh Heupel and Harrell, who now works as USC's offensive coordinator.
4. Mike Leach had a contentious exit from Texas Tech On Dec. 28, 2009 season, Texas Tech suspended Leach while investigating alleged inappropriate treatment of one of his players. Leach allegedly ordered the player in question, Adam James, to stand in an equipment closet during a practice he missed with a concussion.
According to reports at the time of the event, Texas Tech gave Leach until Dec. 28 to apologize to James in writing for the incident. Leach refused to do so.
Leach was fired two days after his suspension began. In a statement released after his dismissal, Leach accused Texas Tech of lying about the situation and said he thinks the lies stemmed from leftover animosity related to contract negotiations from the prior year.
In an interview with the New York Times the day after he was fired, Leach denied the allegations against him, saying he only ordered James be "taken out of the light" due to his condition. Leach also alleged the situation was a result of James' father, former SMU running back and ESPN analyst Craig James, being dissatisfied with his son's lack of playing time.
Leach sued Texas Tech for wrongful termination without cause and for issuing defamatory statements. In 2011, the Texas 7th Court of Appeals ruled in favor of Texas Tech but said Leach was within his right to claim "non-monetary reparations."
In 2012, the Texas Supreme Court denied Leach's petition for review. Leach's defamation lawsuits against ESPN and Craig James were eventually dismissed as well.
5. Mike Leach's personality is large Leach is known for being an eccentric person. He's gained the nickname "the pirate" because of his long-standing fascination with swashbucklers. Dating as far back as 2008, Leach has been known to decorate his office with pirate paraphernalia. According to a New York Times profile of Leach back in 2005, Leach likes to use offseasons to learn everything he can about a specific non-sports topic that interests him, ranging from Geronimo and Jackson Pollock to whales and grizzly bears.
Leach has also been known to tweet bizarre memes and jokes and last spring Leach taught a class at Washington State that covered "insurgent warfare and football."
Contact Nick Suss at 601-408-2674 or nsuss@gannett.com. Follow @nicksuss on Twitter.

OPEN BOOK, FEED SOUL A great selection to keep you busy during cold winter days

Autor: Kale, Wilford. 

Información de publicación: Daily Press ; Newport News, Va. [Newport News, Va]. 10 Jan 2020: M.16.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/open-book-feed-soul-great-selection-keep-you-busy/docview/2334980848/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=OPEN+BOOK%2C+FEED+SOUL+A+great+selection+to+keep+you+busy+during+cold+winter+days&amp;author=Kale%2C+Wilford&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=M.16&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: It's time to sit back in a cozy easy chair, perhaps a couch stacked with cushions, and maybe even beside a fire, pick up a good book and read.
Numerous books - fiction and nonfiction - arrived in 2019 and many are still available in local bookstores and on the internet. There are also a few old favorites from years past still waiting to be enjoyed.
Richmond native and national best-selling author David Baldacci published three new novels in 2019: "A Minute to Midnight: An Atlee Pine Thriller," "One Good Deed," featuring a new character Aloysius Archer, and "Redemption, A Memory Man Thriller." Another Virginia-based author, Rita Mae Brown, has a new book, "Scarlet Fever," a "Sister" Jane Arnold mystery and earlier in the year another novel, "Whiskers in the Dark: A Mrs. Murphy Mystery," co-authored by Sneaky Pie Brown, her cat.
In the murder mystery vein, most of us are familiar with Agatha Christie's "Hercule Poirot" detective novels; another writer in the same genre was Dorothy Sayers. She and her sleuth Lord Peter Wimsey make for a wonderful read on a chilly winter night. These books were popular way back when, but still can be found on the internet and in used book stores. In fact, "Lord Peter: A full collection of all Lord Peter Wimsey Stories," is still available in hardcover and paperback.
On the local front, an important book illustrating the story of the early African American involvement at the College of William & Mary was written by Jacquelyn McLendon, professor of English, emerita was published. "Building on the Legacy: African Americans at William and Mary" includes those first African American students and the growth of the black experience on campus. It also offers a new perspective on the enslaved people who helped build and maintain the institution, an often-overlooked element of the college's story.
Pulitzer Prize winning author Alan Taylor has written a double-faceted book, "Thomas Jefferson's Education," that explores his early education at William & Mary, his educational philosophy and his efforts to establish the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, within sight of his home at Monticello.
2019 was the 75th anniversary of the D-Day invasion, and two significant books related to the events were published: "Every Man a Hero: A Memoir of D-Day, the First Wave at Omaha Beach and a World at War," by Ray Lambert, who is 99 and living in North Carolina, and "The First Wave: The D-Day Warriors Who Led the Way to Victory in World War II," by Alex Kershaw, author of "The Bedford Boys."
Individuals within the scope of American presidential history were the subjects of two important 2019 books: "The Matriarch: Barbara Bush and the Making of an American Dynasty," by Susan Page, USA Today's Washington Bureau Chief and "America's Reluctant Prince: The Life of John F. Kennedy Jr." by Steven M. Gillon, New York Times bestselling author.
Kale writes a biweekly column, Kale on Books, for The Virginia Gazette. Reach him at kaleonbooks@gmail.com.
Caption: Vimvertigo/Getty Images

5 things to know about Mike Leach

Autor: Suss, Nick. 

Información de publicación: Hattiesburg American ; Hattiesburg, Miss. [Hattiesburg, Miss]. 10 Jan 2020: B.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/5-things-know-about-mike-leach/docview/2334980189/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=5+things+to+know+about+Mike+Leach%3A+New+Mississippi+State+leader+brings+18+years+of+experience+as+a+Power+5+head+coach&amp;author=Suss%2C+Nick&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.2&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Hattiesburg+American&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: The Mississippi State football program has announced the hire of Mike Leach, former head coach at Washington State and Texas Tech.
Leach has 18 years of experience as a Power 5 head coach and has led his teams to 16 bowl games. Leach's teams have finished seasons ranked in the top 25 six times, including in 2018 when Washington State went 11-2 and ranked No. 10 in both the AP Top 25 and the Amway Coaches Poll at the end of the season.
Leach is known for being a pioneer of the Air Raid offense and has thrived with quarterbacks putting up eye-popping numbers. He's also known for having a larger-than-life personality in interviews and on Twitter.
Here are five things to know about Mississippi State's new head coach.
1. Mike Leach has a successful track record Leach has a career record of 139-90 in his 18 seasons as a head coach and has led his teams to bowl berths in all but two of those seasons. In 2008, Leach led Texas Tech to an 11-2 record and a Cotton Bowl appearance behind the talents of quarterback Graham Harrell and wide receiver Michael Crabtree.
In 2018, Leach's Washington State Cougars went 11-2 thanks to a record-setting passing season from Mississippi native Gardner Minshew.
Leach has overseen 12 eight-win seasons in his career and has done so in secluded towns like Lubbock, Texas, and Pullman, Washington, that have a reputation for being hard to recruit.
2. Mike Leach loves to throw Leach is a descendant of football legend Hal Mumme's Air Raid passing tree. Leach coached with Mumme at Iowa Wesleyan, Valdosta State and Kentucky, where the pair revolutionized the modern passing offense and thrived with quarterbacks like former No. 1 NFL Draft pick Tim Couch.
Leach continued his pass-first offensive attack for one season as the offensive coordinator at Oklahoma before parlaying those schemes into his head coaching career. Leach's offenses have led the FBS in passing yards per game 10 times in his head coaching career, including each of the last two seasons.
In 2019 alone, Washington State attempted 54.6 pass plays per game. No team finished within 10 pass attempts per game of that mark, with Texas Tech ranking second in the FBS at 44.3 pass plays per game.
3. Mike Leach has a large coaching tree In addition to Leach's success on the field, the coach has done an impressive job of training a generation of offensive minds. Some prominent coaches who have worked under Leach include: SMU coach Sonny Dykes, Houston coach Dana Holgorsen, Oklahoma coach Lincoln Riley, North Texas coach Seth Littrell and former Baylor coach Art Briles.
Leach also coached a large number of players who have become prominent coaches. That list includes: Arizona Cardinals coach Kliff Kingsbury, West Virginia coach Neal Brown, UCF coach Josh Heupel and Harrell, who now works as USC's offensive coordinator.
4. Mike Leach had a contentious exit from Texas Tech On Dec. 28, 2009 season, Texas Tech suspended Leach while investigating alleged inappropriate treatment of one of his players. Leach allegedly ordered the player in question, Adam James, to stand in an equipment closet during a practice he missed with a concussion.
According to reports at the time of the event, Texas Tech gave Leach until Dec. 28 to apologize to James in writing for the incident. Leach refused to do so.
Leach was fired two days after his suspension began. In a statement released after his dismissal, Leach accused Texas Tech of lying about the situation and said he thinks the lies stemmed from leftover animosity related to contract negotiations from the prior year.
In an interview with the New York Times the day after he was fired, Leach denied the allegations against him, saying he only ordered James be "taken out of the light" due to his condition. Leach also alleged the situation was a result of James' father, former SMU running back and ESPN analyst Craig James, being dissatisfied with his son's lack of playing time.
Leach sued Texas Tech for wrongful termination without cause and for issuing defamatory statements. In 2011, the Texas 7th Court of Appeals ruled in favor of Texas Tech but said Leach was within his right to claim "non-monetary reparations."
In 2012, the Texas Supreme Court denied Leach's petition for review. Leach's defamation lawsuits against ESPN and Craig James were eventually dismissed as well.
5. Mike Leach's personality is large Leach is known for being an eccentric person. He's gained the nickname "the pirate" because of his long-standing fascination with swashbucklers. Dating as far back as 2008, Leach has been known to decorate his office with pirate paraphernalia. According to a New York Times profile of Leach back in 2005, Leach likes to use offseasons to learn everything he can about a specific non-sports topic that interests him, ranging from Geronimo and Jackson Pollock to whales and grizzly bears.
Leach has also been known to tweet bizarre memes and jokes and last spring Leach taught a class at Washington State that covered "insurgent warfare and football."
Contact Nick Suss at 601-408-2674 or nsuss@gannett.com. Follow @nicksuss on Twitter.

Facebook Allows Campaigns To Target Voters

Autor: Glazer, Emily. 

Información de publicación: Wall Street Journal , Eastern edition; New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 10 Jan 2020: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/facebook-allows-campaigns-target-voters/docview/2334969230/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Facebook+Allows+Campaigns+To+Target+Voters&amp;author=Glazer%2C+Emily&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=0099-9660&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awallstreetjournal_

Texto completo: In a break with other tech companies, Facebook Inc. said it wouldn't limit how political advertising targets potential voters, but would instead give users tools to see fewer of those ads on its platforms.
Facebook's stance -- that companies shouldn't decide how campaigns are able to reach voters -- is at odds with other tech firms' approach to handling political advertising ahead of the 2020 election.
Operators of online platforms are under increasing pressure to curb the spread of misleading or false information in the wake of the 2016 presidential campaign, which U.S. intelligence agencies have said was subject to foreign meddling online.
Facebook's announcement Thursday highlighted the divide in opinion on what the company's role should be in elections, as critics -- including some Democratic presidential candidates -- said the latest decision leaves the door wide open for disinformation.
Facebook has acknowledged that the spread of disinformation, including through targeted ads, is a problem and has expressed a desire for federal regulation of political advertising online. But its announcement in September that it would exempt politicians' and certain other ads from its third-party fact-checking program fed skepticism about its commitment to combating disinformation on its platform.
The company based its latest decision "on the principle that people should be able to hear from those who wish to lead them, warts and all, and that what they say should be scrutinized and debated in public," according to a blog post from Rob Leathern, Facebook's director of product management. "This does not mean that politicians can say whatever they like in advertisements on Facebook."
The post said all Facebook users have to follow its community standards, which ban hate speech, harmful content and content designed to intimidate voters or stop them from exercising their right to vote.
The company's announcement Thursday also included changes that Facebook said will boost transparency in its ad library relating to how political advertisers deploy their messages on its platforms.
Facebook's approach, including giving users more control over what they see, contrasts with moves by Twitter Inc. and Alphabet Inc.'s Google.
Google earlier this week launched its new policy globally barring advertisers from targeting political messages based on users' interests inferred from their browsing or search histories, among other changes. Twitter stopped accepting most political ads in November.
Facebook acknowledged it considered restricting targeting but chose not to do so.
The Wall Street Journal previously reported Facebook was weighing, among other steps, raising the minimum number of people who can be targeted in political ads on its platform from 100 to a few thousand. The practice known as microtargeting has been criticized for enabling political actors to single out groups for misleading or false ads that aren't exposed to broader public scrutiny.
Facebook said its data showed more than 85% of ad spending by U.S. presidential candidates is for messages aimed at an audience of more than 250,000 people.
The social-media giant said it consulted with a number of nonprofits, political groups and election campaigns -- both Democratic and Republican -- before reaching its decision.
"Ultimately, we don't think decisions about political ads should be made by private companies, which is why we are arguing for regulation that would apply across the industry," Mr. Leathern said, echoing comments Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg has made about the need for federal regulation of political advertising.
Reaction to Facebook's latest decision again showed divergent opinions on how the company should treat political ads.
Trump campaign spokesman Tim Murtaugh said Facebook's decision not to limit targeting allows more Americans to be involved in politics. In any case, he said, there is no escaping political messaging.
"If users do elect to see fewer political ads it still won't stop them from being bombarded by ads from the news media, which are biased and just as political, because there's a loophole in the rule for the media," Mr. Murtaugh said.
Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D., Minn.) criticized Facebook's decision. "Facebook is doubling down on a policy that hurts our democracy," the presidential candidate said in a statement that reiterated her call for comprehensive federal rules on digital political ads.
The campaign of Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden also was critical of the company. "Today's announcement is more window dressing around their decision to allow paid misinformation," said campaign spokesman Bill Russo.
Roughly $3 billion is expected to be spent on political advertising online for the 2020 U.S. election. But with Election Day less than a year away, a lack of uniform rules has led to confusion about exactly what is allowed on digital platforms, how new policies will be enforced and whether advertising strategies and budgets will need to change further.
Facebook's announcement comes two days after the New York Times reported on an internal post by Facebook executive Andrew Bosworth, in which he said he believed the platform played a central role in the 2016 presidential election.
"So was Facebook responsible for Donald Trump getting elected? I think the answer is yes, but not for the reasons anyone thinks. He didn't get elected because of Russia or misinformation or Cambridge Analytica. He got elected because he ran the single best digital ad campaign I've ever seen from any advertiser. Period," Mr. Bosworth wrote.
Facebook said it aims to roll out its new user-control feature in the U.S. early this summer on its main platform and on Instagram.
Facebook said while its users have been able to hide all messages from a specific advertiser in their ad preferences, they soon will be able to stop seeing ads based on how an advertiser constructed its list of targeted users.

Credit: By Emily Glazer

OFFICIALS: IRANIAN MISSILE BROUGHT DOWN JET EVIDENCE SUGGESTS TRAGEDY ACCIDENTAL

Autor: Post-Gazette wire services. 

Información de publicación: Pittsburgh Post - Gazette ; Pittsburgh, Pa. [Pittsburgh, Pa]. 10 Jan 2020: A-1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/officials-iranian-missile-brought-down-jet/docview/2334966150/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=OFFICIALS%3A+IRANIAN+MISSILE+BROUGHT+DOWN+JET+EVIDENCE+SUGGESTS+TRAGEDY+ACCIDENTAL&amp;author=Post-Gazette+wire+services&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A-1&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Pittsburgh+Post+-+Gazette&amp;issn=1068-624X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: WASHINGTON - An Iranian missile accidentally brought down a Ukrainian jetliner over Iran this week, killing everyone aboard, American and allied officials said on Thursday, adding a tragic coda to the escalated military conflict between Washington and Tehran.
Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada said his country had intelligence that an Iranian surface-to-air missile brought down the jetliner, which was carrying 63 Canadians among its some 176 passengers and crew. Mr. Trudeau said his conclusion was based on a preliminary review of the evidence but called for a full investigation "to be convinced beyond all doubt."
"We recognize that this may have been done accidentally," Mr. Trudeau said at a news conference in Ottawa. "The evidence suggests very clearly a possible and probable cause for the crash."
United States officials had a "high level of confidence" that the Iranians brought down the airliner by mistake, one American official said. The official said two missiles fired from an Iranian air defense system, the SA-15, shot down the airliner.
The Ukrainian airliner, a Boeing 737-800, went down on Wednesday morning. It had turned back toward the Tehran airport before it crashed in a huge explosion minutes after takeoff, according to an initial Iranian report released on Thursday. The report said the plane, bound for Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, was in flames before it hit the ground but did not send a distress signal.
Although both the United States and Iran now appear to be backing away from a larger military confrontation, the new intelligence suggests that the loss of life from the downing of the plane was a direct result of those heightened tensions between the countries.
American satellites, designed to track missile launches, detected the firing of the Iranian short-range interceptor. U.S. intelligence agencies later intercepted Iranian communications confirming that the SA-15 system brought down the Ukrainian airliner, officials said.
A security camera captured the impact - first the predawn darkness, then a series of blinding bursts of light in the distance, followed by a storm of burning debris in the foreground.
The circumstances of the disaster raised suspicions that the airliner was brought down by a missile. The crash occurred just hours after Iran launched a barrage of ballistic missiles at U.S. targets in Iraq, with Tehran presumably bracing for possible American retaliation.
American officials have been reluctant to publicly assign blame for the downing of the aircraft, apparently to keep from inflaming tensions with Iran, at a time both governments were taking steps to de-escalate the military confrontation that came to a head when an American drone killed Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani, one of the most senior figures in Iran's government.
The SA-15 missile is designed to operate at medium to very low altitude and intercept both aircraft and guided weapons, according to military documents. It has a maximum range of 15.5 miles and can intercept aircraft and missiles at an altitude of up to 32,800 feet.
A mobile system, the SA-15 could have been brought out by the Iranian military to defend the airport if officials believed the U.S. military was intending to counterattack after the missile strike. If the Iranians thought that the United States was going to target their airport or other facilities with guided missiles, the SA-15 system could have been used to try to intercept them.
The SA-15 can track multiple targets, and seek to shoot down two at once, meaning it can fire multiple missiles nearly simultaneously, according to the military documents.
The comments from American officials came after the Iranians invited the National Transportation Safety Board of the United States to assist in the investigation despite previous reports that the Americans would not be involved, according to correspondence reviewed by The New York Times.
The board has reached out to the State Department to determine how to proceed, according to two people familiar with the matter who spoke on condition of anonymity because the correspondence was not public. Sanctions against Iran prevent Boeing from contacting the Iranians without an export license, the people said.
On Wednesday, a spokesman for Iran's armed forces, Abolfazl Shekarchi, was quoted by the Iranian news media as saying that the crash was not a result of any military action.
"This is ridiculous," Mr. Shekarchi was quoted as saying. "Most of the passengers on this flight were our valued young Iranian men and women. Whatever we do, we do it for the protection and defense of our country and our people."

'UGLY BETTY' WRITER, PRODUCER AUG. 14, 1974 - JAN. 7, 2019

Autor: CNN. 

Información de publicación: Pittsburgh Post - Gazette ; Pittsburgh, Pa. [Pittsburgh, Pa]. 10 Jan 2020: C-9.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ugly-betty-writer-producer-aug-14-1974-jan-7-2019/docview/2334966085/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=%27UGLY+BETTY%27+WRITER%2C+PRODUCER+AUG.+14%2C+1974+-+JAN.+7%2C+2019&amp;author=CNN&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C-9&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Pittsburgh+Post+-+Gazette&amp;issn=1068-624X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Silvio Horta, 'Ugly Betty' creator
Silvio Horta, best known as a writer and producer of ABC's popular series "Ugly Betty," died Tuesday, his family announced. He was 45.
"It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our dear brother and son, Silvio Horta," a statement from his mother Anna and sister Hilda Horta read. "Through his friendships, his love and his work in TV and films, Silvio touched the lives of millions."
"Silvio had an ongoing struggle with addiction and depression, but through it all, he always found a way to turn his struggle into laughter," the statement added. "He was a kind and beautiful man. He may be gone but his light will shine on."
Mr. Horta died by suicide, according to the Miami-Dade Medical Examiner.
"Ugly Betty" followed the adventures of Betty Suarez (portrayed by America Ferrera), a cheerful, fashion-challenged young Mexican American woman from Queens, N.Y., who lands a job as an assistant at a fashion magazine in Manhattan. The show was an adaptation of a wildly popular Colombian telenovela, "Yo Soy Betty, La Fea."
Ms. Ferrera paid tribute to Mr. Horta on Tuesday. "I'm stunned and heartbroken to hear the devastating news of Ugly Betty creator, Silvio Horta's death," she wrote in a caption of a photo showing her with Mr. Horta and "Ugly Betty" producer Salma Hayek after a win at the Golden Globes. "His talent and creativity brought me and so many others such joy&light."
In a 2013 interview with the Television Academy Foundation, Mr. Horta said he believed his show's legacy would be "bringing a unique, diverse face to television" as well as highlighting social issues.
Mr. Horta, a first-generation Cuban American, was born Aug. 14, 1974, in Miami. He broke out in 1998 with his screenplay for slasher film "Urban Legend," which starred Jared Leto and Alicia Witt. In the early 2000s, Mr. Horta was also known for writing sci-fi series "The Chronicle" and for creating another series, "Jake 2.0," which starred Christopher Gorham.
Mr. Horta's most recent producing and writing credit was a 2015 movie on NBC, "The Curse of the Fuentes Women."
The toll-free National Suicide Prevention Lifeline number is 1-800-273-TALK (8255).
The New York Times and Syracuse Media Group contributed.

Here's a royal pain plenty of us could stand

Autor: Teitell, Beth. 

Información de publicación: Boston Globe ; Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass]. 10 Jan 2020: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/heres-royal-pain-plenty-us-could-stand/docview/2334963873/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Here%27s+a+royal+pain+plenty+of+us+could+stand&amp;author=Teitell%2C+Beth&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Boston+Globe&amp;issn=0743-1791&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Can commoners ditch their duties, too — from the laundry, grocery shopping, work deadlines, making nice with the extended family?
Asking for a friend.
To recap the #Megxit drama: Harry, Meghan, and baby Archie went on the lam after announcing Wednesday that they were going to “step back" from royal duties. Meghan's grandmother-in-law (a.k.a. Queen “The Crown" Elizabeth) turned publicly passive-aggressive, and Buckingham Palace issued a statement about "complicated issues that will take time to work through."
The couple's “take-this-job-and-shove-it" moment, delivered on Instagram, tops the fed-up flight attendant of 2010 who cursed passengers over the PA system, then exited by way of the escape chute, becoming a folk hero along the way.
That guy was later arrested. And who knows? With the queen reportedly seeking a quick resolution to the scandal — maybe by now Buckingham Palace guards have rounded up the rogue royals, and Harry is in the back of a horse-drawn carriage muttering, “Just when I thought I was out, they pull me back in."
But back in the real world, where access to money, celebrities, and air travel with no checked-bag fees are what people fantasize about escaping to , the royals' move has nonetheless captivated the public.
“That was the first thing I thought of — I would like to step back from my duties," said Alison Dagnes, a political science professor, the author of books on scandal, and perhaps most pertinent, the mother of two.
“They don't tell you this when you're a kid, but there's a lot to do," she said. “My students are so excited to go off into the 'real world' and I'm like, 'Don't do it!' "
In Boston, a middle-aged woman who comes from a large, contentious clan fantasized about stepping away from her familial duties and alerting her dear ones via social media, not in person.
“The beauty of it was that Meghan and Harry didn't even need to talk to the relatives," said the woman, who didn't want to be named for fear of family wrath. “They didn't have to see their tears, the anger, the threats."
Americans who have become certified royal experts by watching “The Crown" know that being a royal can be extremely boring. Dressing, dealing with protocol, giving and receiving little bows. Like you'd almost rather be in a human resources meeting about a proposed change in mileage reimbursement.
Those who have obsessively followed Meghan — who know, say, that Misha Nonoo the clothing designer, is a BFF — understand that things have not been easy for her. That what at first looked like a great role in fact carried stress beyond the pressure to appear delighted 24/7 and sit so your legs cross primly at the ankles.
As The New York Times reported, “She was too bold, too outspoken, too difficult, too American, too multicultural, the critics said. She should not have alienated the news media by refusing to join in their celebrity games. She should not have spent so much money renovating the house the royal family was kind enough to bestow upon her and her husband."
Within minutes of the young royals' announcement, media coverage reached a saturation point that even President Trump might envy, but even so, questions remain unanswered:
Are Meghan and Harry still on the Amazon Prime account? Will the queen turn their home, Frogmore Cottage, into a gym? How will Kate and Will explain this to George, Charlotte, and Louis (when he's older)?
(Suggested consumer story for British papers: “How to talk to the heirs about their uncle and aunt stepping back from their duties.")
How long have M & H been plotting this? They haven't even been married for that long. But the Daily Mail is reporting that the couple trademarked over 100 items, from hoodies to socks “SIX MONTHS before they split with the monarchy."
In many ways, this royal diss is so far removed from commoners' lives it's hard to relate to.
Most people who leave the family business don't have their wax likenesses removed from London's Madame Tussauds museum, for example.
But wax or not, they are subject to the same laws of human emotion as the rest of us, said Sherry Kuehl, author of the “Snarky in the Suburbs" books.
“Take 'royal' out of it and they're just a family," she said. “There are going to be chasms in that relationship that will never be healed. I think they're going to be lonely."
Perhaps, but at least they'll have gotten out of all those duties.
Beth Teitell can be reached at beth.teitell@globe.com. Follow her on Twitter @bethteitell.

What's On Friday

Autor: Cohn, Gabe. 

Información de publicación: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 10 Jan 2020: C.11.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/whats-on-friday/docview/2334957161/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=What%27s+On+Friday%3A+%5BMovies%2C+Performing+Arts%2FWeekend+Desk%5D&amp;author=Cohn%2C+Gabe&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.11&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;issn=0362-4331&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anytimes_

Texto completo: A thriller series based on a Jeffery Deaver novel debuts on NBC. And RuPaul stars in a new Netflix comedy series.
What's on TV
LINCOLN RHYME: HUNT FOR THE BONE COLLECTOR 8 p.m. on NBC. Human bones are strewn about New York in "The Bone Collector," Jeffery Deaver's 1997 novel about Lincoln Rhyme, a forensics expert who solves cases without leaving his apartment. He works with a younger detective who does the ground work in tracing a serial killer. The book was adapted into a 1999 feature with Denzel Washington and Angelina Jolie, who had only the roughly two-hour running time of the film to crack the case. This new TV series adaptation should give its stars more wiggle room. It casts Russell Hornsby as Rhyme, who is left unable to walk after an injury on the job. So he works remotely, electronically communicating with a young officer (played by Arielle Kebbel), who pursues the case's mysteries with Rhyme in her ear.
BILL BURR PRESENTS: THE RINGERS 11 p.m. on Comedy Central. The comedians Rosebud Baker, Jordan Temple and Josh Adam Meyers will be the first to appear on this new stand-up show from Bill Burr. Episodes are a sampler of rising talent, with three comics each performing a short set, after briefinterviews with Burr. It's an opportunity, Burr explains, for the comics to net "a TV credit that'll get you a hotel room where your door opens up to the hallway, rather than a parking lot."
What's Streaming
AJ AND THE QUEEN Stream on Netflix. "I'm not your mother," RuPaul Charles says in this new comedy series, "I'm a drag queen on a cross-country tour." He's talking to AJ (Izzy Gaspersz), a neglected 10-year-old who covertly hitches a ride as Charles's character, Ruby Red, sets off on a road trip. Turns out they kind of need each other: Each is leaving behind a troubled past, and they help each other work through that as they travel the country by mobile home. Their first stop: Pittsburgh. It's a city, Ruby Red tells AJ, where everyone is so friendly, "it's like going back in time."
THE LITTLE STRANGER (2018) Stream on HBO platforms. Domhnall Gleeson plays a doctor to haunted British blue bloods in this horror movie, an adaptation of a Gothic novel by Sarah Waters. Directed by Lenny Abrahamson ("Room"), the film is set around a sprawling estate in Warwickshire, England, in the late 1940s. There's suspense in the air -- plenty of mysterious, spooky episodes can found here -- but there's also a heavy amount of social commentary: This is a stately home in decline, and the story is told through Gleeson's character, a commoner who wouldn't be permitted to get comfortable there even if it weren't possibly haunted. "The twisting and cracking of the British class system is always fascinating to observe, and 'The Little Stranger' traces the details of its chosen moment of social change with precision and subtlety," A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times, "and with its own layers of somewhat dubious nostalgia."
Photograph Russell Hornsby, left, Michael Imperioli and Arielle Kebbel. (PHOTOGRAPH BY ZACH DILGARD/NBC); RuPaul Charles, left, and Izzy Gaspersz. (PHOTOGRAPH BY BETH DUBBER/NETFLIX); Domhnall Gleeson (PHOTOGRAPH BY NICOLA DOVE/FOCUS FEATURES)

CONFLICT WITH IRAN; Iran probably downed jet by accident, officials say

Autor: Cloud, David S. 

Información de publicación: Los Angeles Times ; Los Angeles, Calif. [Los Angeles, Calif]. 10 Jan 2020: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/conflict-with-iran-probably-downed-jet-accident/docview/2334956824/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=CONFLICT+WITH+IRAN%3B+Iran+probably+downed+jet+by+accident%2C+officials+say&amp;author=Cloud%2C+David+S&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2020-01-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Los+Angeles+Times&amp;issn=0458-3035&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Alatimes_

Texto completo: The Ukrainian jet that crashed near Tehran this week, killing all 176 people on board, was probably shot down accidentally by Iranian surface-to-air missiles, U.S. and Canadian officials said Thursday.
U.S. intelligence analysts reached the conclusion after reviewing satellite images and other intelligence that indicated Iran's forces fired two Russian-made SA-15 antiaircraft missiles at the jet shortly after it took off from Tehran's airport, a U.S. official familiar with the finding said.
Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau had made public similar conclusions earlier in the day.

"We have intelligence from multiple sources, including our allies and our own intelligence," Trudeau said. "The news will undoubtedly come as a further shock to the families who are already grieving in the face of this unspeakable tragedy."
The crash came just a few hours after Iran launched a ballistic missile attack against Iraqi military bases housing American troops amid a confrontation with Washington over the U.S. drone strike that killed an Iranian Revolutionary Guard general last week.
Two U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive intelligence, said they had no certain knowledge of Iranian intent. But they said the airliner could have been mistaken for a threat.
The New York Times published a video Thursday that it said appears to show the plane being hit by a missile.
President Trump suggested that he believed Iran was responsible but wouldn't directly blame the Iranians. He dismissed Iran's initial claim that it was a mechanical issue.
"Somebody could have made a mistake on the other side," Trump said, noting the plane was flying in a "pretty rough neighborhood."
"Some people say it was mechanical," Trump added. "I personally don't think that's even a question."
Iran on Thursday rejected the claim that the plane was brought down by its missiles, calling the claim "a very well-calculated move" and "a lie" by the United States.
"It is regrettable that the U.S. government's psychological operations system and its informed or uninformed allies are adding salt to the pains of the bereaved families with these lies and victimize affected families to reach their goals in the psychological operations," Ali Rabiei, an Iranian government spokesman, said in a statement.
The statement also included an invitation to Boeing, as the airliner's manufacturer, and to France, where the engine was built, to participate in the investigation.
The airline's owner, a Ukrainian company, has already sent investigators.
It was not immediately clear how the U.S. and its allies would react to the downing of the airliner. At least 63 Canadians and 11 Ukrainians were among the dead.
Despite efforts by Washington and Tehran to step back from the brink of possible war, the region remained on edge after the killing of the Iranian general and Iran's retaliatory missile strikes. U.S. troops were on high alert.
The latest assessment came just a day after Defense Secretary Mark Esper and Army Gen. Mark Milley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said they hadn't had a chance to review the intelligence on the incident.
Both spent much of the day at the White House and on Capitol Hill briefing the administration on the killing of Gen. Qassem Suleimani and the resulting attacks by Iran.
A preliminary Iranian investigative report released Thursday said that the airliner pilots never made a radio call for help and that the burning aircraft was trying to turn back for the airport when it went down.
The plane crashed just minutes after taking off from Imam Khomeini International Airport in Tehran, the main airport for travelers in Iran.
Iranian officials initially blamed a technical malfunction for the crash.
Both of the "black boxes" that contain data and cockpit communications from the plane had been recovered, though they sustained damage and some parts of their memory were lost.
Hours before the plane crash, the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration had issued an emergency flight restriction barring U.S. carriers and pilots from flying over areas of Iraqi, Iranian and some Persian Gulf airspace, warning of the "potential for miscalculation or misidentification" for civilian aircraft due to heightened political and military tensions.
Ukraine has a grim history with missile attacks, including in July 2014 when one such strike downed a Malaysia Airlines flight over eastern Ukraine, killing all 298 people aboard.
The plane in this week's crash was carrying 167 passengers and nine crew members from several countries, including 82 Iranians, officials said.
Many passengers were believed to be international students attending universities in Canada; they were making their way back to Toronto by way of Kyiv, Ukraine, after visiting family during the winter break.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said he planned to call Iranian President Hassan Rouhani about the crash and the investigation.
The crash ranked among the worst losses of life for Canadians in an aviation disaster. The flag over Parliament in Ottawa was lowered to half-staff, and Prime Minister Trudeau vowed to get to the bottom of the disaster.
--
Times staff writer Chris Megerian and the Associated Press contributed to this report.
