When bitter is good

Autor: Asimov, Eric. 

Información de publicación: Chicago Tribune ; Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill]. 09 Jan 2020: 16.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/when-bitter-is-good/docview/2334606677/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=When+bitter+is+good%3A+Understanding+how+the+flavor+can+enhance+your+wine&amp;author=Asimov%2C+Eric&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=16&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Chicago+Tribune&amp;issn=1085-6706&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Achicagotribune_

Texto completo: Many good wines have a built-in defense against being consumed by children: They are inherently bitter, a flavor that children seem genetically hard-wired to abhor.
Eventually, taste buds evolve. Young adults come to love many bitter flavors, whether in beer, dark chocolate, arugula, Negronis, coffee or tea.
Despite the prevalence of bitter flavors in popular foods and beverages, many people resist the idea that bitterness can be a positive. The old saw has it that American wine consumers talk dry but drink sweet.
The negative connotation of bitterness extends to wine descriptions. Despite the many examples of excellent wines that contain bitter flavors, no producers want to associate their wine with the word bitter. Few consumers would find such a description to be particularly attractive.
Wine marketers know that the public will flock to wines described as smooth, silky, velvety, fruit-forward, spicy, bold and rich. Bitter? Not so much.
I'm hoping that 2020 might be a year for rehabilitating the notion of bitterness in wine. I started to think about this on a trip in November to northern Italy, a land where bitter flavors seem to be built into the cuisine.
On arriving in Milan, I had dinner at Carlo e Camilla, a restaurant serving creative interpretations of northern Italian food in a beautifully restored old mill.
Seeking a bit of warming comfort on a cold, rainy night, I ordered a glass of Valpolicella Classico and was delighted with its clear-as-a-bell flavors, ringing of tart cherry and ending with a refreshing bitterness that prompted the next sip.
The next day, I finished a quick pizza lunch with an espresso, pulled and poured into a tiny cup. It was the proverbial Italian coffee experience, just enough to bolt in one go -- This one was ideal: smooth, radiant in flavor, bitter at the end and perfectly refreshing.
That night at dinner at Trattoria Masuelli San Marco, a traditional Milanese restaurant with a blessedly regional wine list, I drank an excellent Barolo Bricco Delle Viole 2007 from G.D. Vajra, vibrant and expressive with a touch of welcome bitterness as the other flavors faded away.
These beverages, though very different, had in common that punctuating bitterness. In each case, it was both cleansing and revitalizing, an acknowledgment of what had come before and a shift in attention to what would come next.
This attractive bitterness is one component of a spectrum of flavors that evolve directly from the fermentation of wine grapes. Wine can offer other forms of bitterness that may not always be so pleasing.
Tannic red wines can be astringent, a drying sensation in the mouth that can be experienced as bitter. Tannins that are part of a harmonious whole don't bother me, so long as they suit the intent of the wine.
I expect a top Barolo or Bordeaux to be tannic in youth. These tannins might be fine and barely detectable, yet firm enough to wrap up the flavors and nuances of the wines for quite a few years until they integrate. Then the youthful bitterness and astringency will largely evaporate to reveal the complexities within.
Similarly, a rustic young red from southern Italy might be robustly tannic yet still be a pleasure to drink, the astringency and bitterness of the tannins balancing out the sweet fruit.
Tannins generally come from the skins, seeds and stems of grapes, which is why white wines are rarely tannic. To provide wine with color, red grapes are crushed and macerated with their skins, and sometimes seeds and stems. To avoid color in white wines, the juice is whisked away from the pigment-bearing skins, with a notable exception.
That is the category of orange wines, white wines made as if they were reds, macerated with their skins until they take on an amber tinge. Depending on how long the juice stays in contact with the skins, these wines can become starkly tannic and quite bitter. It's all a matter of balance.
I find the welcome sort of bitterness most often in Italian reds. It doesn't matter which region or what grape, it seems to cut across both, whether Valpolicella of the Veneto, Barbera d'Asti of the Piedmont, Chianti Classico of Tuscany, the aglianicos of Campania or the Etna rossos of Sicily.
I find it in French wines, too, though not as pervasively. Good Beaujolais often has a welcome bitter component, as do the syrahs of the Northern Rhone, Bordeaux and cabernet francs of the Loire. In Spain, I sense it in traditionally made Riojas and the mencias of Ribeira Sacra.
Alcohol level plays a role, though. The higher the alcohol, particularly when you get to the range of 14.5% and above, the more likely a wine's procession of flavors will culminate in sweetness rather than bitterness. This is partly because of the elevated amount of glycerol found in high-alcohol wines. The combination of fruitiness, alcohol and glycerol contributes to a perception of sweetness, even if the wine contains no residual sugar.
The alcohol level in American wines can often provide a clue as to whether the wine will have a refreshing snappiness, of which bitterness is a component, or a flabby sweetness.
Sweet flavors of course are highly popular, whether in some of America's most expensive cult wines or in mass-produced supermarket wines. I don't quibble with anybody who enjoys them.
But stay aware of the flavors that make so many red wines so delicious, as well as other foods. Perhaps we can make 2020 a bitter year, and I mean that in the best possible way.<
CAPTION: Photo: Despite the prevalence of bitter flavors in popular foods and beverages, many people resist the idea that bitterness can be a positive. Maybe 2020 will be a year for rehabilitating the notion of bitterness in wine. GAIA STELLA/THE NEW YORK TIMES; Photo: MICHAEL TERCHA/CHICAGO TRIBUNE<
CREDIT: By Eric Asimov, The New York Times

Church forced to learn to fight back Deadly plot against Ga. congregation uncovered in time

Autor: Burch, Audra DS. 

Información de publicación: Orlando Sentinel ; Orlando, Fla. [Orlando, Fla]. 09 Jan 2020: A.14.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/church-forced-learn-fight-back-deadly-plot/docview/2334599124/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Church+forced+to+learn+to+fight+back+Deadly+plot+against+Ga.+congregation+uncovered+in+time&amp;author=Burch%2C+Audra+DS&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.14&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Orlando+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: GAINESVILLE, Ga. - The tiny white church has new locks, peepholes and brass plates. While its parishioners pray, the sanctuary is bolted shut and a police officer is now stationed outside. Soon, surveillance cameras will be installed, and the 47-member congregation will participate in active-shooter training.
This is the next chapter for the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church, which the authorities said was targeted in mid-November. Gainesville police charged a 16-year-old white girl with planning a racially motivated knife attack to kill the black worshippers, a plot they said bore eerie similarity to a 2015 massacre at a storied African American church in Charleston, South Carolina.
In Gainesville, a small city of 40,000 residents in the heart of Georgia's poultry industry, the police chief has urged church members to use low-tech force to protect themselves. They should hurl Bibles or hot coffee, chairs or fire extinguishers, anything, he said, that can be weaponized if they are under attack and cannot safely escape.
"It's a shame that we live in a world today where we have to protect our institutions of worship, our schools, but evil knows where we are most vulnerable," Chief Jay Parrish told church leaders during a recent introduction to the active-shooter training. "The lightning bolt got too close this time."
Faced with a rise in attacks on houses of worship, the Rev. Michelle Rizer-Pool, the pastor of Bethel, and other religious leaders across the country are fortifying their buildings and preparing for the possibility of mass shootings. Some have also turned to armed security and organized law enforcement patrols.
Last week, a gunman opened fire during Sunday service at a Texas church, killing two congregants before an armed member of the church's volunteer security team fatally shot him. And over the past two years, gunmen have targeted worshippers at synagogues in Poway, California, where one person died, and in Pittsburgh, where a man shouting anti-Semitic slurs gunned down 11 people, and at a Baptist church in Sutherland Springs, Texas, where 26 people were killed and 20 more were wounded.
"Unfortunately, this is what it has come to. We have to be ready to fight back," said Rizer-Pool, a retired Army major who has led Bethel for about 18 months. "We are having to get our arms around this idea of praying and praising our God in what is supposed to be a place of peace, but having to be watchful and on the lookout."
Faith groups have responded to the growing threat of hate crimes and violence, in part, by offering specialized training and producing safety guides. The Council on American-Islamic Relations published a safety manual for religious institutions and began holding training sessions after a mass shooting at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin in 2012.
"Our thinking is, if you substitute 'mosque' for 'church' or 'synagogue' or 'temple,' the concerns are the same, so we made the guide available to the entire faith community," said Ibrahim Hooper, national communications director for the group.
After a gunman stormed the small church in Sutherland Springs in November 2017, a Dallas-area megachurch organized an active-shooter training session, which more than 600 church leaders from across the country attended. Since then, the church and the Southern Baptists of Texas Convention have provided training and security assessments at 150 churches in Texas, Oregon and Missouri. Texas legislators responded, too, by passing laws that allow anyone with a concealed-carry license to bring firearms into churches.
In Gainesville, 55 miles northeast of Atlanta, the police department has conducted training and security assessments across the city since a gunman stormed an elementary school in Newtown, Connecticut, and killed 26 people, including 20 children, in 2012.
At Bethel on one recent dreary Saturday morning, after the hymn, the prayer and the scripture reading, Parrish and Sgt. Kevin Holbrook talked to the church's leadership about fear - and fighting back. They had gathered in a backroom to discuss the creation of a security team and response plan to protect the congregation.
The new reality, the police officers said, calls for adding a layer of vigilance to the church's general culture and spirit of inclusion. Now, parishioners need to know alternate exits. They need to make eye contact with visitors. They need to set up patrol details.
But the most important strategy, the officers said, is knowing how to react if attacked: Run, hide or fight. Run to safety; hide from the attacker; or, as a last resort, fight back with anything available.
"A fire extinguisher makes a huge cloud, and if it gets on your skin, it burns. If it gets in your eyes, it blinds. And if you get hit in the head with it, it will knock you out," Parrish said. "If you have to fight, know you're fighting for your life."
The Gainesville High School student arrested a few weeks before this training session was on a mission to kill Bethel church members, the authorities said. In a carefully orchestrated plan, they said, the teenage girl acquired butcher knives, researched online, took meticulous notes and had scouted the church's location on Mill Street.
On the day she went to the church - either to launch the attack or to collect more information, the police said - she found an empty building. Authorities said the girl's plan was likely inspired by Dylann Roof, the convicted white supremacist who murdered nine worshippers during Bible study at a church of the same denomination, Emanuel AME, in Charleston, South Carolina.
The Gainesville plot was foiled by classmates who told a high school counselor about the girl's notebook, which contained the chilling plans. Police said the level of detail in her notes may have saved Bethel.
The student, who has not been identified by the authorities, was charged with criminal intent to commit murder.
Though police said her plan was racially motivated, she was not charged with a hate crime because the state is one of four across the country with no such law. But after the planned attack was made public, a group of black legislators announced that they would continue to push for a bill to create stiffer penalties for crimes motivated by hate.

Iranians in Louisville don't mourn Soleimani, but worry over fallout

Autor: Kenning, Chris. 

Información de publicación: Courier - Journal ; Louisville, Ky. [Louisville, Ky]. 09 Jan 2020: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/iranians-louisville-dont-mourn-soleimani-worry/docview/2334598732/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Iranians+in+Louisville+don%27t+mourn+Soleimani%2C+but+worry+over+fallout&amp;author=Kenning%2C+Chris&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Courier+-+Journal&amp;issn=1930-2177&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: Some residents of the local Iranian community declined to comment because they feared relatives could be targeted in Iran or be barred from traveling back and forth on either side.
Shortly after Iran fired ballistic missiles at a military base in Iraq housing U.S. troops on Tuesday night, Iranian-born Naeim Torkian's phone lit up.
"Everyone was like, 'Oh my God, war is started,'" the Louisville valet worker said of his Iranian friends and family in the U.S. and abroad, who have spent days on edge after the U.S. killed Iran's top general over the weekend.
At the same time, Babak Rezaei, 32, who came to Louisville from Iran as a refugee, was inundated with calls and texts from family and friends in Iran: "They didn't know what the U.S. reaction would be. They were asking if they should pack and run away, go to the mountains."
He told them, "I'm not sure. I'm not in the room to know what Trump is thinking. Just be prepared for the worst."
One local Iranian American family canceled flights for a family visit, he said, while others remembered all too vividly the backlash from the 1979 Iranian hostage crisis, a time when bumper stickers said, "Iranians Go Home."
But by Wednesday, some in Louisville's Iranian American community, which Rezaei estimated at several thousand, said fears about war in the Middle East and the fallout in the U.S. gave way to signs that the situation was deescalating — at least for now.
Iran's missile attack on an Iraqi base housing U.S. troops may have purposely avoided any casualties or major damage, and statements from both sides appeared to suggest both were looking to calm the open conflict that ramped up after the assassination of Gen. Qassem Soleimani.
Few Iranian Americans in Louisville and elsewhere were mourning the death of Soleimani. Rezaei said he believes that Soleimani was "a murderer" whose proxy militias killed U.S. troops and oppressed Iranians inside its borders, despite the estimated 1 million people who turned out for his funeral in Tehran.
"A friend of mine texted me right away and said Soleimani is killed, and he had a happy face," he said of the former leader of Iran's elite Quds Force.
But as Iranian Americans across the country debated how the clash would impact terrorist attacks in the Middle East and recent protests against the Iranian regime, some worried about the conflict's potential consequences for family.
Louisville resident Shahab Taheri, 23, whose family came to the U.S. for more opportunity, said his father, a dentist, still hasn't been admitted back to the U.S. after visiting home in Shiraz, Iran, in February 2018. He said President Donald Trump's "travel ban" restrictions on seven majority-Muslim nations, including Iran, are to blame.
That has left the rest of the family to operate a small sandwich restaurant in his absence, leading to strains.
"Because of the travel ban, he hasn't been able to get a visa," Taheri said. The latest tensions are "just going to make things worse."
Meanwhile, some residents of the local Iranian community declined to comment because they feared relatives could be targeted in Iran or be barred from traveling back and forth on either side.
Weighing heavily were media reports that U.S. Department of Homeland Security officials detained dozens of Iranian travelers returning from work trips or vacations and held them for hours at the Canadian border in Washington State over the weekend.
The New York Times reported that when one family asked agents why they were being questioned, an officer told them, "This is a bad time to be an Iranian."
"Every Iranian in the U.S. right now is worried," Rezaei said. "They don't want their loyalty and love for the U.S. questioned, and at the same time, what if Iran responded and somebody got killed, what is the next step? There is so much baggage" between the two nations, he said.
On Wednesday, the National Iranian American Council issued a statement expressing concern about the rocket attacks but laid blame for the conflict on Trump.
"Donald Trump owns this 100%. He inherited a working nuclear deal and a tense but stable situation with Iran. He has deeply wounded the first major diplomatic initiative between the U.S. and Iranian government in decades, and listened to ideologues who convinced him to assassinate an Iranian general. At every step of the way, he has been warned he risked moving back on the path to war. Now that day may be here," the group said.
Iranian Americans in the U.S. are estimated to number up to 1 million, according to the U.S. State Department, including thousands in the years before and after the 1979 Iranian Revolution.
Rezaei, now a middle school teacher with two children, came later after growing up in the small city of Masjed Soleiman. His father, an engineer, spent several years in prison in Iran for being a political activist seeking a more secular government.
After his father was again detained for questioning in 2005, the family left for Turkey. Rezaei was granted political asylum in the U.S., and the rest of his family was resettled in the Netherlands. Now a U.S. citizen, he didn't vote for Trump or Hillary Clinton in the last election, he said.
But, he said, "going to war with Iraq wasn't justified and wasn't necessary, and if not for the removal of Saddam Hussein, Iran wouldn't be emboldened enough to become a major player in the Middle East."
As tensions in a long-running shadow war recently escalated, he said many Iranians thought open conflict could break out in June, when Iran shot down a U.S. drone. But Trump called off a retaliatory strike because of the potential loss of life.
He said it seemed Trump "had had enough" after Iranian-backed Shiite militias surrounded and attacked the U.S. embassy in Baghdad, perhaps stirring memories of Iranian protesters taking over the U.S. embassy 1979 and holding hostages.
After Soleimani was killed, he was shocked. "I didn't think Trump would go that far," he said.
He believes it helped unite conservative Iranians, possibly undercutting recent anti-government protests in Iran amid high inflation and unemployment fueled by U.S. sanctions.
Others debated Trump's threats to attack cultural sites, which drew worries and condemnation, including from U.S. Rep. John Yarmuth, Kentucky's only Democrat in Washington.
For his part, Torkian, who now lives in Jeffersonville, Indiana, said he came to the U.S. in 2011 as a refugee from Iran, where he was part of a religious minority that suffered discrimination.
He said some including in the U.S. still count Soleimani as a hero, and he's been blocked by friends on social media for calling him a criminal. His family in several Iranian cities, including Tehran, remain "worried about war," he said
Iran's supreme leader, Ali Khamenei, dubbed Tuesday's missile attack as a "slap in the face" to the U.S., and another top official said its missile attack had concluded.
On Wednesday, Trump said Iran "appears to be standing down," and threatened Iran with additional sanctions. He also appeared to offer the Iranians an olive branch, signaling the United States does not seek a war with Tehran.
"The United States is ready to embrace peace with all who seek it," Trump said.
As some Iranian Americans wonder what's next, Taheri said that if no one is hurt or killed, "I think it's going to fade away, and there's not going to be any war. At least, I hope so."
Reporter Chris Kenning can be reached at ckenning@gannett.com or 502-396-3361.

Bogus 'guardians' steal nest eggs, sometimes life

Autor: EDITORIAL BOARD. 

Información de publicación: The News Press ; Fort Myers, Fla. [Fort Myers, Fla]. 09 Jan 2020: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bogus-guardians-steal-nest-eggs-sometimes-life/docview/2334598457/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Bogus+%27guardians%27+steal+nest+eggs%2C+sometimes+life&amp;author=EDITORIAL+BOARD&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+News+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: The concept of "retirement," along with government social welfare programs to support old folks who no longer worked, dates to the 1880s. That's when German Chancellor Otto von Bismarck concluded that a little socialism for the elderly — Germany set retirement its age at 70 — was better than blanket entitlement programs for all his constituents.
As Bismarck's idea circulated across the Atlantic, Florida didn't take long to catch on. The New York Times noted a few years ago that by 1910 middle-class retirees joined the wealthy in discovering the Sunshine State as an appealing place to live out their golden years. Retirement communities began popping up within the next two decades.
Thus, for a century Florida has marketed itself and catered to the elderly, becoming a top destination of elders seeking a retirement pasture.
But that influx of senior citizens made Florida a target-rich environment for hucksters, shysters and ne'er do wells out to con them — or harm them in other ways. And on occasion that abuse came from those entrusted to watch out for their interests.
Now, state Rep. Colleen Burton has joined an effort to better protect our seniors.
The Lakeland Republican has sponsored a bill that would toughen oversight of the state's guardianship program for seniors, which is managed by the state Department of Elder Affairs.
Focus on this arm of the tiny agency began last summer after media reports surfaced about Rebecca Fierle, an Orlando-based guardian. The Florida Department of Law Enforcement investigated her after one of her clients, Steven Stryker, 75, died from choking on food while hospitalized in Tampa. Fierle reportedly filed a "do not resuscitate" order, which precluded hospital staff from treating Stryker, without permission from either Stryker or his family.
Subsequently, an audit by Orange County determined Fierle had billed Advent Health more than $4 million over 10 years, double-billing the hospital system and court for the same services. Fierle also had clients in Volusia and Flagler counties, and after news of the Tampa case broke, Volusia County Circuit Judge Margaret Hudson started requiring that guardians seeking a DNR appear before her for an evidentiary hearing with medical testimony and notice to the ward's family.
A few months before Stryker's case became news, the website RealClearInvestigations.com reported on Lillie White, an 88-year-old from Palm Coast. During an August 2016 doctor's appointment, while her niece remained in the waiting room, a guardian took White and declined to say where she went. Two years later White's family learned that her sole granddaughter, who had been cut out of White's will, had persuaded a judge White needed guardianship.
White, who was worth $4 million, was housed in an assisted living facility 35 miles from home. The guardian, without White's family's knowledge, sold her house and some of her other assets to pay the fees of the guardian as well as a court-appointed lawyer and other people overseeing her case.
We believe that most of the state's 500-plus guardians are professional, conscientious, devoted to the best interests of their wards and law-abiding.
But as noted above, some are not. In order to protect Florida's elderly who need this service, as well as the state's reputation as a haven for senior citizens, we must have stricter rules governing this program. For working for that, we applaud Rep. Burton and Sen. Passidomo.
This editorial was originally published in the Lakeland Ledger.
CREDIT: Editorial Board

The outdoor dining dome trend has come to the Fox Cities

Autor: Nyman, Shane. 

Información de publicación: The Post - Crescent ; Appleton, Wis. [Appleton, Wis]. 09 Jan 2020: B.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/outdoor-dining-dome-trend-has-come-fox-cities/docview/2334598309/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=The+outdoor+dining+dome+trend+has+come+to+the+Fox+Cities&amp;author=Nyman%2C+Shane&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.2&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Post+-+Crescent&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: GRAND CHUTE - Sure, outdoor patio dining can be a year-round thing in Wisconsin.
All it takes is a heated "igloo."
That's what the employees at the DoubleTree by Hilton hotel (formerly a Holiday Inn) at 150 Nicolet Road are calling their newly-installed domes, now open for restaurant and bar patrons looking to spend some time in the hotel courtyard in single-digit temps.
The outdoor domes are an eating-and-drinking trend of late, with the New York Times a few days ago declaring them "everywhere this winter" in the city. They've popped up in the Milwaukee area in recent years, including with Café Benelux in the Third Ward finding success with rooftop domes. Lodge Kohler is promoting some as opening soon in Green Bay. They're surfacing in Michigan, too, including at a popular brewpub in the Upper Peninsula.
The DoubleTree has three of the domes set up in the courtyard outside the hotel restaurant, the Watermark. Each sits a maximum of six people and they can be reserved for no more than two hours. There also is a $100 minimum for the food and drink tab.
The dome walls are a see-through plastic (or plastic-like material) and each shelter is screwed into the concrete. They are carpeted, decorated with lights and throw blankets and have a zippered door like a tent would have to enter and exit.
Most importantly, each one also has a space heater.
Steve Madson came to the Grand Chute hotel to be the food and beverage manager about six months ago. Before that he'd worked at a Hilton hotel in Wausau that successfully brought in a few of these wintertime domes. He wanted to do the same here.
"It's a novelty," Madson said. " ... It's just something different. You can't get it anywhere else."
The hope is for the domes to attract Fox Cities residents looking for a new and fun experience. Many of the hotel guests are business travelers, Madson said, so getting a group together outside isn't really an option for them.
Both Madson and hotel sales administrator Jessica Kerwin said they haven't heard of any other place in the Fox Cities with igloos. It's likely this is the first — and using other areas as a reference point, unlikely to be the last.
Know of another place with domes, or plans to have them this winter? Contact Shane Nyman at 920-996-7223 or snyman@gannett.com. Follow him on Twitter at @shanenyman.
CREDIT: Shane Nyman

How a Nigerian writer found a home in Vermont

Autor: Fornarola, Isaac. 

Información de publicación: The Burlington Free Press ; Burlington, Vt. [Burlington, Vt]. 09 Jan 2020: A.4.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/how-nigerian-writer-found-home-vermont/docview/2334598034/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=How+a+Nigerian+writer+found+a+home+in+Vermont%3A+In+her+work%2C+Ukamaka+Olisakwe+takes+intrepid+dives+into+the+deeply+personal&amp;author=Fornarola%2C+Isaac&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Burlington+Free+Press&amp;issn=0894-8844&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: What lures a novelist from Nigeria to Vermont?
Nature or quietude, one might guess. But for Ukamaka Olisakwe, a Montpelier-based screenwriter, novelist and poet, the draw was Shonda Rhymes.
"I like to tell anyone who asks me this question that I came here because I wanted a quiet place away from city noises so I can concentrate and create meaningful art," Olisakwe said. "But the truth is I fell in love with Vermont after watching Shonda Rhimes' 'Scandal.' "
"Scandal" is a political drama about a D.C. fixer named Olivia Pope (played by Kerry Washington) that ran from 2012 to 2018.
"There is a very romantic episode set in Vermont called 'Vermont is for Lovers, Too,' " Olisakwe said, in which a character brings Olivia, his love interest, to see the house they would have lived in had things been different for them. "I immediately knew I wanted to see that state."
That, and a friend from Nigeria had recommended the Master of Fine Arts program at the Vermont College of Fine Arts in Montpelier, where Olisakwe is a degree candidate.
In her work, Olisakwe takes intrepid dives into the deeply personal. She's written about motherhood, postpartum trauma, and growing up Christian during a time of fraught violence between Christians and Muslims in northern Nigeria.
Olisakwe has been featured in the New York Times and published two books: "Eyes of a Goddess," her first, was published in 2012. She describes her debut novel as "speculative fiction that follows the tumultuous life of a teenage humangoddess." Her second, "Ogadinma," will be published in the spring of 2020.
We caught up with her about who inspires her, what she's reading now, and her best advice for how to write about what scares you.
This interview has been edited for clarity and concision.
Q: How did you know you wanted to pursue writing?
A: I think I was too busy raising my children and being a wife to care about writing, until I got a job at a local bank and met people who read my simple correspondences and thought I always reached for a clear narrative arc in my emails. They encouraged me to take this writing thing seriously. That was in 2010. I am glad I listened.
Q: What other careers did you consider before deciding on writing?
A: I worked in sales and marketing for a local bank in Nigeria, and also worked as a customer service officer for a different bank. I enjoyed both jobs but looking back, I was exasperated all the time because of the unfair conditions and also because there was no safety in them. But they gave me the background I needed and the inspiration for my TV series, "The Calabash", which I wrote over a course of one year and was aired on Africa's biggest network –DSTV, in 2015.
Q: Are there still things you're afraid to write about? How do you overcome fear in writing about the deeply personal?
A: I recently published a very personal essay that explored my experiences with childbirth and my postpartum trauma. That was the most terrifying thing I had ever done. Having done that – having confronted that fear and survived it – I do not think there is anything I can't now not write. It took a long time to get here, and my mental health took a lot of beating because of this. But I survived it and it is thanks to the community of women I have surrounded myself with, who continually tell me that my story is valid, that my voice is strong, that it is okay to face this fear, to speak. Their support brought down the bricks of fear I had walled myself with.
Q: You came to America in 2018, a tumultuous time. What do you see as the primary role of a writer in a time when political tempers are running high?
I love E.B. White's response to the question about responsibility of a writer at a time like this. He said, "A writer should concern himself with whatever absorbs his fancy, stirs his heart, and unlimbers his typewriter. I feel no obligation to deal with politics. I do feel a responsibility to society because of going into print: a writer has the duty to be good, not lousy; true, not false; lively, not dull; accurate, not full of error. He should tend to lift people up, not lower them down. Writers do not merely reflect and interpret life, they inform and shape life."
Q: What has been the most stark difference between Nigeria and your life in Vermont?
Quietude. My city, Aba, is a fun, loud commercial place with about a million people. Montpelier has less than 8,000 people, and it reminds me of my hometown in Abagana. All that foliage and the small-town niceness. It reminds so much about home.
Still, I miss the noise of Aba, the highlife music, even the food. But I have been able to produce more creative work within a very short period since I moved here.
Q: Do you have any Vermont writers with whom you're close or whose work you admire?
A: I had the privilege of working with the poet Bianca Stone at the Vermont College of Fine Arts; she opened my eyes to the wild things I could do with poetry. I am also currently working with Frances Cannon, an illustrator and writer, whose recent graphic book, Walter Benjamin Reimagined, shows the amazing things we can do when we bend genres.
Q: What's the best piece of writing advice you've ever received?
A: To read widely and across genres, because when you do this, when you read beyond your comfort zone, beyond the constricting categorizations that tend to separate the 'literary' from the 'commercial', you will be amazed by what you learn. You will have a broader playing field.
Q: What is the biggest misconception Vermonters have about Nigerians?
A: I sincerely do not know what Vermonters think about Nigeria, given that there's this stark disparity in the racial demography here.
But in general, I like to think that Nigerians are perceived as high achievers and I shamelessly chuckle when I hear people say this. We work so hard. We are awake when others are asleep. We want to make a point about black success, especially in a country that's still rife with racial segregation. We want to go back home to our relatives with news of our successes abroad. Every time I click on a journal and spot a Nigerian-looking name, I do cartwheels and pump the air in celebration, even though I don't personally know the writers.
Q: You write extensively about marriage, motherhood and childbirth. What other work has informed your writing? What work would you recommend to people looking to explore those topics?
A: I have read everything Lesley Nneka Arimah has written, everything by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Buchi Emecheta, Flora Nwapa, Lola Shoneyin, and many others. My critical analysis of their works has helped frame the structure and context of my own story. They captured the realities of Nigerian women in the past and present, and their works do not gloss over the subtle religious and cultural norms that contribute to our psychological makeup.
I also recommend Carmen Maria Machado's debut memoir "In the Dream House" and Yiyun Li's memoir "Dear Friend, from My life I Write to You in Your Life." These works opened my eyes to how the passage of time affects how vulnerable we can be on the page, with significant gap in time serving as the psychological distance we need before we can coherently and clearly articulate our traumatic experiences. The purpose of the distancing from the source of trauma allows our work to not appear too raw on the page, undigested.
Q: What are you reading right now?
A: I am reading Abi Dare's "The Girl With the Louding Voice."
Q: What do you still hope to see while you're in Vermont?
A: A teeming Nigerian community. That is all I hope for.

Vermont-based writer Ukamaka Olisakwe is the author of two novels, including the forthcoming "Ogadinma," due out in 2020.

After 100 years, we're in a crossword 'golden age'

Autor: McDonald, Terrence T. 

Información de publicación: The Journal News ; White Plains, N.Y. [White Plains, N.Y]. 09 Jan 2020: N.4.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/after-100-years-were-crossword-golden-age/docview/2334597939/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=After+100+years%2C+we%27re+in+a+crossword+%27golden+age%27&amp;author=McDonald%2C+Terrence+T&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=N.4&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Journal+News&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: In 1924, the U.K.-based newspaper The Tamworth Herald warned of a dangerous craze that had "enslaved" the United States.
The paper described a "menace ... making devastating inroads on the working hours of every rank of society." People were "shamelessly" participating at all hours of the day. It was dealing "the final blow to the art of conversation."
The culprit? Crossword puzzles.
Yep, crossword puzzles, those grids of black-and-white blocks and often pun-ny clues that appear in the pages of newspapers. They were all the rage in the 1920s, until the nationwide fad eventually died along with the Charleston and pole-sitting.
Nearly a century later and we're in the "golden age of crosswords." Or so says Will Shortz. He should know: Shortz has been the editor of the storied New York Times crossword puzzle since 1993, and before that worked at Games magazine for 15 years.
"They have never been as popular, with the possible exception of 1924," Shortz, who lives in Pleasantville, told NorthJersey.com. "Now crosswords are more up to date, they're livelier, they feel more modern. I think they're attracting a wider audience than ever."
'A good kind of torture' Once upon a time, crossword fans had to rely on newspapers, magazines or published puzzle books to get their fix. Now you can solve them on your tablet or phone via apps (USA TODAY's crossword app was a big hit with its readers), or subscription-based sites like The Inkubator and Fireball Crosswords can send them to your inbox. You can sign up for Queer Crosswords or Women of Letters by donating to specific charities.
"Now there are so many other options and venues," said Anna Gundlach, a puzzle fan and crossword constructor who lives in Portland, Oregon. "A lot of the distribution channels are able to be bypassed entirely."
The proliferation of independent crossword puzzles means a wider range of clues and answers and more provocative content. Puzzle editors at the New York Times reject puzzles if they decide a clue or answer is too obscure. Gundlach said the paper passed on one of hers because it referenced Bell Biv DeVoe.
"The American Values Club, which I've done a crossword for recently, has a more Gen X, millennial bent to it," she said. "Fresher clues, not afraid to swear or talk about sex."
Gundlach has had a nearly lifelong puzzle obsession. For Howard Barkin, a love of crosswords came late. He started solving them in his early 30s during lunch breaks to get his mind off work. Now he's 45 and a legit crossword puzzle champion. Barkin, who lives in Somerset County, finished first in the 2016 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament in Stamford, Connecticut.
Shortz is the director for the contest, which pits the best crossword solvers against one another in seven games over the course of a weekend, culminating in a final round for the three finalists. Barkin's tournament victory came after solving the last puzzle in 7 minutes, 49 seconds.
The stress was high, Barkin said.
"Most people aren't used to solving a crossword with a timer counting down in a room full of 500 people," he said.
Barkin also constructs crosswords when he frees time between doing dishes and raising two young daughters. He said his favorite to solve involve "extremely evil" tricks.
"A puzzle that breaks the rules, but for a good reason," he said. "A puzzle where you have to write a Greek letter into a square or something. It's a good kind of torture."
'Wow us' Even with a host of alternatives, the gold standard crossword remains the one The New York Times publishes.
"It's capital T, capital C: The Crossword," Gundlach said. "When people talk about 'the Sunday crossword' or 'the Friday crossword,' that's generally assumed to be the New York Times crossword."
Crossword fans use the hashtag #NYTXW on Twitter to brag about their finish times and offer their often-harsh criticism of that day's puzzle. The Dec. 12 crossword elicited reviews like "Ugh. So Bible heavy and then that twist? No." and "Ok #NYTXW sorry I don't know the ATOMIC NUMBER of NEODYMIUM?!?!"
The paper's associate puzzles editor, Sam Ezersky, doesn't take that kind of criticism personally. His Facebook banner photo is a foul-mouthed pan of one of his crossword puzzles.
"It's an obsessive culture," Ezersky said. "I get being so passionate about something like this."
Ezersky grew up in a Washington, D.C., suburb as a puzzles fanatic and sold his first crossword puzzle to the Los Angeles Times when he was 16 years old. He's 24 now, lives in Hoboken, New Jersey, and spends his days sifting through some of the roughly 600 crossword puzzle submissions the New York Times receives monthly (via snail mail only). Some he turns down with nothing more than a glance. Either the grid is an odd pattern, or the words are meh.
"We're just looking for fresh things that really capture our attention," he said. "These days we really need the puzzles to wow us."
Ezersky does not construct puzzles as much as he used to, but he snagged a dream assignment this year, creating the annual "super mega" crossword that ran Dec. 15 in the New York Times' special puzzles section. It was a massive undertaking: a 50x50-square grid with 708 answers. It's so big the clues are printed on a separate page. Ezersky estimates it took hundreds of hours to construct. Still, he would have begged to do it if necessary.
"I know there were other constructors that declined because it's a such a Herculean task," he said. "If I could have been totally no filter and not cared about professionality, I would have been like, 'Please, please, please, please, please.'"
An Ezersky crossword from August shows how his mind works when he puzzles out a puzzle. He began with the across answer at the bottom left, where he placed "tech-savvy." He then stacked "heist film" right on top, giving himself the unenviable challenge of finding a down answer that ends with "lv." He did: "capital V."
Once the grid is done, he dreams up clues. He clued "tech-savvy" with "E-sharp?" – that question mark is crossword-ese indicating there's a joke or pun involved – and asked readers to get to "capital V" with the clue "Symbol for 54-down." The answer was "volts."
Constructing crossword puzzles can be agonizing, Ezersky said, but he wouldn't want any other job.
"My mantra to myself is I'm just getting started," he said. "I'm just humbled and grateful to be doing what I'm doing."

Nesting grounds tarred and no longer feathered Paving of HRBT south island for expansion displaces 25,000 birds

Autor: Rago, Gordon. 

Información de publicación: Daily Press ; Newport News, Va. [Newport News, Va]. 09 Jan 2020: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/nesting-grounds-tarred-no-longer-feathered-paving/docview/2334597607/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Nesting+grounds+tarred+and+no+longer+feathered+Paving+of+HRBT+south+island+for+expansion+displaces+25%2C000+birds&amp;author=Rago%2C+Gordon&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Twenty-five thousand seabirds have lost their 40-year-old nesting site on an island along the Hampton Roads Bridge-Tunnel.
It just got paved over.
A little over a month ago, crews finished paving the entire south island to prepare for the $3.862 billion project, a Virginia Department of Transportation spokeswoman said. A new island for the birds will not be constructed as part of the expansion, though transportation officials did work since 2017 with researchers and other federal agencies to try to come up with another place for them to live.
What that means for the 25,000 birds that have nested there since the early 1980s is unclear. The spokeswoman said VDOT will have to wait and see what the birds do when they return from their trip south in April. Researchers surmise some will likely hang around and try to lay eggs while others will fly off to find another spot to call home.
While the south island of the bridge-tunnel, so close to speeding cars, is a peculiar site for birds, researchers say it's unlikely that any other site in the state could successfully maintain the community of terns, black skimmers and gulls. Researchers say it's the largest seabird colony in Virginia.
That will likely mean population declines for species like the gull-billed tern, listed as threatened under the Virginia endangered species act. Also affected will be the royal tern: The south island provides breeding habitat for 98% of that species in Virginia.
"There's no doubt that there will be thousands of birds that will come back this spring," said Jim Fraser, a professor of wildlife conservation at Virginia Tech who VDOT contracted to study the bird population and come up with solutions, possibly another island. "It's really hard to predict what will happen."
They'll still be able to eat the plentiful fish, but without a spot to nest they might get themselves in trouble by roosting at the nearby airport.
Still, good news might be on the horizon.
In October, the Department of Game and Inland Fisheries submitted a formal request to the Army Corps of Engineers to use dredged material to build a bird island, said the agency's executive director Ryan Brown. That could be a long ways off, up to a couple years, Brown said. The agency is still waiting to see if it could get the material and does not yet know how much an island would cost.
"Our main focus is the birds right now," said Paige Pearson, spokeswoman for the game department. "We're trying to figure out the best thing for them."
The birds' future has been made more precarious because of the Trump administration, which came out with an interpretation in 2017 of the century-old Migratory Bird Treaty Act.
It all but ends punishment for bird deaths from "incidental bird takes," or destruction of nests during something like construction, according to The New York Times. If the purpose or intent of the activity is not to take birds, nests or eggs, then it is no longer prohibited. The administration has discouraged local governments and businesses from taking precautionary measures to protect birds, The Times reported.
The rollback of the act led a group of attorneys general to sue the Interior Department, which oversees the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. A group of former Interior Department appointees called for an end to the opinion.
Now, Virginia is not required to provide mitigation like building a new island as it starts construction on the bridge-tunnel.
In Virginia, efforts to find a new home for the birds go back about three years and have faced a number of roadblocks including federal permitting, protection of fish habitats and safety concerns around U.S. naval airspace.
Virginia Tech researchers gave VDOT a number of options such as stringing together 24 barges along the east side of the island. They looked at expanding the south island by four acres near Fort Wool, which is on the National Register of Historic Places. Early discussions even included the option of the birds using an island 68 miles away.
VDOT came close to developing an elbow-shaped portion of land on Willoughby Spit, once eyed for condo development. The Navy ultimately quashed that, writing to the state in May 2018 that the birds would pose a danger to pilots who use the airspace.
Virginia Tech professors had their minds set on building a new island nearby. The birds like islands because of the lack of mainland predators like raccoons and foxes and because of the rich food source in the waters below, researchers said. They've nested on the south island because of threats from those animals as well as development around the Eastern Shore.
"Habitat for birds like terns in the lower bay is really at a premium now, and most of the areas they were able to nest in have been developed in some form or fashion," said Michael Parr, president of the D.C.-based nonprofit American Bird Conservancy.
Still, even the new island idea came with concerns. Biologists with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration warned that building a 10-acre island in the middle of Hampton Roads would impact habitat for the dozen fish species in the area. While building a structure could attract some species of fish, it would take away habitat for others like those species that use the bottom, said Dave O'Brien, a fisheries biologist with the agency. It could also impact fish migratory patterns.
Plus it could cost several millions of dollars, though an Army Corps program could bring the price tag way down.
That back-and-forth about options for the seabirds continued until June 2018, when the researchers felt VDOT stopped responding.
The reason, they say, is the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service told them continued conservation efforts for migratory birds are now "purely voluntary," in accordance with the 2017 interpretation, according to a copy of the letter obtained by The Times.
If the state is successful in building an island for the birds, Fraser is optimistic they will come back.
"If you build it they will come," he said.
Gordon Rago, gordon.rago@pilotonline.com, 757-446-2601
Caption: Daily Press file
A tern sits in its nest on the south island of the HRBT.

Iran missile attacks, Australian wildfires, Puerto Rico earthquakes: 5 things to know Thursday

Información de publicación: USA Today (Online) ; Arlington [Arlington]. 09 Jan 2020.

Resumen: House to vote whether to limit Trump's war power, Australian wildfires continue to wreck havoc and more things to start your Thursday morning right.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Iran+missile+attacks%2C+Australian+wildfires%2C+Puerto+Rico+earthquakes%3A+5+things+to+know+Thursday&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=USA+Today+%28Online%29&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anorthcentralnews_

Texto completo: House will vote to limit Trump's war power amid concerns on Iran strategy
The House will vote Thursday on a measure that would limit President Donald Trump's ability to wage war with Iran. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Trump's action last week — authorizing a drone strike that killed top Iranian General Qasem Soleimani — was "provocative and disproportionate" and done without consulting Congress. But even if the measure passes the House, which is controlled by Democrats, it will face hurdles in the GOP-controlled Senate. And Trump can veto the measure, as he did last year when Congress tried to end the American military role in Yemen.

Trump takes re-election message to Ohio
The commander in chief will hold his first rally of 2020 Thursday in Ohio, an important swing state that supported him in 2016. The "Keep America Great" rally will be held in the Huntington Center in downtown Toledo. Trump easily won Ohio by 8 percentage points over Democrat Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential election, although he lost in Toledo. Trump's visit comes amid increased tension between the U. S. and Iran. On Wednesday, Trump threatened Iran with additional sanctions following Iran's rocket attack on airbases in Iraq housing U. S. troops.

Puerto Rico earthquake: Many still left without power
Government inspectors on Thursday are expected to visit one of the hardest-hit towns affected by the string of earthquakes in Puerto Rico, according to the New York Times. The worst quake — a magnitude 6. 4 that struck early Tuesday — killed at least one person, injured at least nine and caused the power outage that has left about half a million people in the U. S. territory without electricity. The powerful quake was the strongest the island has seen in more than a century and comes as many areas are still recovering from the devastation of the deadly Hurricane Maria in 2017, which killed thousands. Punta Ventana, a coastal rock formation that had formed a sort of rounded window, and other popular landmarks were damaged by the quakes, officials said.

Will Harry and Meghan's royal bombshell upstage Duchess Kate's birthday?
While Duchess Kate celebrates her 38th birthday on Thursday, royal fans are eagerly waiting to learn more about Prince Harry and Duchess Meghan's stunning decision to step down from their senior royal roles. The couple, who also confirmed that they intend to split their time between North America and the United Kingdom, also said they're working on becoming "financially independent. " After their announcement came a palace statement, suggesting that some in the royal family were not amused. "We understand their desire to take a different approach, but these are complicated issues that will take time to work through," the statement said.

Australian wildfires: Residents urged to flee as hot, windy conditions escalate
The unprecedented wildfires in Australia, which have killed at least 25 people and destroyed 2,000 homes, are expected to escalate Thursday, according to the Associated Press. Residents in the path of infernos razing southeastern Australia were urged to evacuate as hot and windy conditions are forecast in the region. Experts say climate change has increased bushfire risk in Australia by lengthening the fire season, decreasing precipitation and increasing temperature. The U. S. State Department upped its travel warning level for Australia on Wednesday and recommended that tourists consider postponing their trips.

When bitter is a good thing How it can enhance your wine

Autor: Asimov, Eric. 

Información de publicación: Orlando Sentinel ; Orlando, Fla. [Orlando, Fla]. 09 Jan 2020: D.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/when-bitter-is-good-thing-how-can-enhance-your/docview/2334597234/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=When+bitter+is+a+good+thing+How+it+can+enhance+your+wine&amp;author=Asimov%2C+Eric&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.2&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Orlando+Sentinel&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Many good wines have a built-in defense against being consumed by children: They are inherently bitter, a flavor that children seem genetically hard-wired to abhor.
Eventually, taste buds evolve. Young adults come to love many bitter flavors, whether in beer, dark chocolate, arugula, Negronis, coffee or tea.
Despite the prevalence of bitter flavors in popular foods and beverages, many people resist the idea that bitterness can be a positive. The old saw has it that American wine consumers talk dry but drink sweet.
The negative connotation of bitterness extends to wine descriptions. Despite the many examples of excellent wines that contain bitter flavors, no producers want to associate their wine with the word bitter. Few consumers would find such a description to be particularly attractive.
Wine marketers know that the public will flock to wines described as smooth, silky, velvety, fruit-forward, spicy, bold and rich. Bitter? Not so much.
I'm hoping that 2020 might be a year for rehabilitating the notion of bitterness in wine. I started to think about this on a trip in November to northern Italy, a land where bitter flavors seem to be built into the cuisine.
On arriving in Milan, I had dinner at Carlo e Camilla, a restaurant serving creative interpretations of northern Italian food in a beautifully restored old mill.
Seeking a bit of warming comfort on a cold, rainy night, I ordered a glass of Valpolicella Classico and was delighted with its clear-as-a-bell flavors, ringing of tart cherry and ending with a refreshing bitterness that prompted the next sip.
The next day, I finished a quick pizza lunch with an espresso, pulled and poured into a tiny cup. It was the proverbial Italian coffee experience, just enough to bolt in one go - This one was ideal: smooth, radiant in flavor, bitter at the end and perfectly refreshing.
That night at dinner at Trattoria Masuelli San Marco, a traditional Milanese restaurant with a blessedly regional wine list, I drank an excellent Barolo Bricco Delle Viole 2007 from G.D. Vajra, vibrant and expressive with a touch of welcome bitterness as the other flavors faded away.
These beverages, though very different, had in common that punctuating bitterness. In each case, it was both cleansing and revitalizing, an acknowledgment of what had come before and a shift in attention to what would come next.
This attractive bitterness is one component of a spectrum of flavors that evolve directly from the fermentation of wine grapes. Wine can offer other forms of bitterness that may not always be so pleasing.
Tannic red wines can be astringent, a drying sensation in the mouth that can be experienced as bitter. Tannins that are part of a harmonious whole don't bother me, so long as they suit the intent of the wine.
I expect a top Barolo or Bordeaux to be tannic in youth. These tannins might be fine and barely detectable, yet firm enough to wrap up the flavors and nuances of the wines for quite a few years until they integrate. Then the youthful bitterness and astringency will largely evaporate to reveal the complexities within.
Similarly, a rustic young red from southern Italy might be robustly tannic yet still be a pleasure to drink, the astringency and bitterness of the tannins balancing out the sweet fruit.
Tannins generally come from the skins, seeds and stems of grapes, which is why white wines are rarely tannic. To provide wine with color, red grapes are crushed and macerated with their skins, and sometimes seeds and stems. To avoid color in white wines, the juice is whisked away from the pigment-bearing skins, with a notable exception.
That is the category of orange wines, white wines made as if they were reds, macerated with their skins until they take on an amber tinge. Depending on how long the juice stays in contact with the skins, these wines can become starkly tannic and quite bitter. It's all a matter of balance.
I find the welcome sort of bitterness most often in Italian reds. It doesn't matter which region or what grape, it seems to cut across both, whether Valpolicella of the Veneto, Barbera d'Asti of the Piedmont, Chianti Classico of Tuscany, the aglianicos of Campania or the Etna rossos of Sicily.
I find it in French wines, too, though not as pervasively. Good Beaujolais often has a welcome bitter component, as do the syrahs of the Northern Rhone, Bordeaux and cabernet francs of the Loire. In Spain, I sense it in traditionally made Riojas and the mencias of Ribeira Sacra.
Alcohol level plays a role, though. The higher the alcohol, particularly when you get to the range of 14.5% and above, the more likely a wine's procession of flavors will culminate in sweetness rather than bitterness. This is partly because of the elevated amount of glycerol found in high-alcohol wines. The combination of fruitiness, alcohol and glycerol contributes to a perception of sweetness, even if the wine contains no residual sugar.
The alcohol level in American wines can often provide a clue as to whether the wine will have a refreshing snappiness, of which bitterness is a component, or a flabby sweetness.
Sweet flavors of course are highly popular, whether in some of America's most expensive cult wines or in mass-produced supermarket wines. I don't quibble with anybody who enjoys them.
But stay aware of the flavors that make so many red wines so delicious, as well as other foods. Perhaps we can make 2020 a bitter year, and I mean that in the best possible way.

New book in the works

Autor: Devine, Jacqueline. 

Información de publicación: Las Cruces Sun - News ; Las Cruces, N.M. [Las Cruces, N.M]. 09 Jan 2020: A.8.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/new-book-works/docview/2334597131/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=New+book+in+the+works&amp;author=Devine%2C+Jacqueline&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Las+Cruces+Sun+-+News&amp;issn=1081-2172&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: Editor's note: Jennifer Cervantes is among our 2020 Movers & Shakers — profiles on people or groups expected to shape Las Cruces in the coming year.
LAS CRUCES - Las Cruces-based children's author Jennifer Cervantes — pen name J.C. Cervantes — had a great year in 2019, landing on the New York Times Best Sellers list, and shows no signs of slowing in 2020.
This year, fans can expect the third and highly anticipated book of Cervantes' "The Storm Runner Series." Also, you might be seeing the series' characters on screen soon.
"I can't give specifics yet, but I can tell you that it's been optioned for television," she said.
Cervantes, 49, didn't imagine herself becoming an author while growing up, but she's been a success since her first foray into the business.
Her first book, "Tortilla Sun," published in 2010, won a New Mexico Book Award and Zia Book Award, among many other accolades.
Next, she began writing a trilogy for young adults that follows the story of a young New Mexican boy named Zane Obispo and his three-legged dog named Rosie. Zane meets with colorful characters inspired by Mayan mythology in his adventures.
The first book of the series, "The Storm Runner," published in September 2018 and landed on the New York Times Best Sellers list. The second book, "The Fire Keeper," debuted at No. 4 on the list when in published in September 2019.
The third book, "The Shadow Crosser," will be released Sept. 1, 2020.
Cervantes is the second author to publish under Rick Riordan Presents, a Disney-Hyperion imprint, headed by Riordan, best-selling author of the "Percy Jackson" series.
"The platform that they have created has been nothing short of remarkable and is so necessary in this changing industry," she said.
Also, Cervantes said she's finished up a young adult novel that should be announced soon. "And after that? A couple more books are in the works that I can't wait to talk about," she said.
On tour Now that she's a New York Times best selling author, Cervantes said "so much is the same and so much is different."
"I still get up every day and face the page with both enthusiasm and doubt," she said. "But I also now have this platform that allows me to reach more readers and connect with more kids and that's one of the best parts of this job."
In 2019, she went on a book tour and traveled to conferences and festivals all over the country.
"When I am on the road, I often tell people about the magic of the Land of Enchantment," Cervantes said. "There is an uncompromising natural beauty here and we are so fortunate to call this place home."
Cervantes said she hopes to continue writing stories for as long as she can for anyone who will read them.
"My goal is to keep writing books that connect kids and readers to something greater than themselves," she said. "Books that offer a frame for dreaming, imagining, learning, and growing."
Once upon a time ... When Cervantes was a girl, she said she didn't think about becoming an author.
"While I have always been a voracious reader, I didn't realize my passion for writing until later," she said. "I look up to so many people in the writing world who are doing amazing work — from editors and agents, to other authors and community organizers."
Cervantes, a San Diego native, attended both the University of New Mexico and New Mexico State University where she earned her bachelor's in communication studies and a master's in rhetoric and professional communication.
Cervantes met her husband, Joseph Cervantes, who is a state senator and last year ran for governor, while she was a student at UNM. The couple have three daughters, Alexandra, 25, Isabella, 24, and Juliana, 20.
Aside from being a best-selling author, Cervantes has worn many hats in Las Cruces and has volunteered on several boards and several other charitable organizations.
She is a former executive director of the Community Foundation of Southern New Mexico which fosters and expands the nonprofit industry in Doña Ana, Grant, Hidalgo, Lincoln, Luna, Otero and Sierra counties.
Cervantes said she is now focusing 100% percent on writing.
"I'm incredibly proud of the body of work I have created. Every time I sit down to write a new book, I wonder if I can do it again. It's just part of the process," Cervantes said, adding that she's "astonished" she was able to pen a trilogy.
"Writing a multi-book series is a bit like swimming in the ocean without a life vest," she said. "But that's the beauty of art. It allows you to reach for the horizon in increments. Inch by inch just to see what's on the other side."
Cervantes encourages writers young and old to follow their dreams if they wish to be an author one day.
"My advice for anyone who wants to write is read widely, follow your heart and write what moves you, don't let the critics in too soon, study your craft and be kind," she said.
For information on Cervantes, visit www.jennifercervantes.com/ or follow her on Twitter, @jencerv and Instagram, @authorjcervantes
Jacqueline Devine can be reached at 575-541-5476, JDevine@lcsun-news.com or @JackieIsDevine on Twitter.
Jennifer Cervantes signs her book, "Storm Runner" for Kelley Coffeen during the book-signing event on September 22, 2018.

After 100 years, we're in a crossword 'golden age'

Autor: McDonald, Terrence T. 

Información de publicación: The Journal News ; White Plains, N.Y. [White Plains, N.Y]. 09 Jan 2020: K.6. [Duplicado]

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/after-100-years-were-crossword-golden-age/docview/2334596863/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=After+100+years%2C+we%27re+in+a+crossword+%27golden+age%27&amp;author=McDonald%2C+Terrence+T&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=K.6&amp;date=2020-01-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Journal+News&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: "They have never been as popular, with the possible exception of 1924. Now crosswords are more up to date, they're livelier, they feel more modern."
Will Shortz
New York Times crossword puzzle editor
In 1924, the U.K.-based newspaper The Tamworth Herald warned of a dangerous craze that had "enslaved" the United States.
The paper described a "menace ... making devastating inroads on the working hours of every rank of society." People were "shamelessly" participating at all hours of the day. It was dealing "the final blow to the art of conversation."
The culprit? Crossword puzzles.
Yep, crossword puzzles, those grids of black-and-white blocks and often pun-ny clues that appear in the pages of newspapers. They were all the rage in the 1920s, until the nationwide fad eventually died along with the Charleston and pole-sitting.
Nearly a century later and we're in the "golden age of crosswords." Or so says Will Shortz. He should know: Shortz has been the editor of the storied New York Times crossword puzzle since 1993, and before that worked at Games magazine for 15 years.
"They have never been as popular, with the possible exception of 1924," Shortz, who lives in Pleasantville, told NorthJersey.com. "Now crosswords are more up to date, they're livelier, they feel more modern. I think they're attracting a wider audience than ever."
'A good kind of torture' Once upon a time, crossword fans had to rely on newspapers, magazines or published puzzle books to get their fix. Now you can solve them on your tablet or phone via apps (USA TODAY's crossword app was a big hit with its readers), or subscription-based sites like The Inkubator and Fireball Crosswords can send them to your inbox. You can sign up for Queer Crosswords or Women of Letters by donating to specific charities.
"Now there are so many other options and venues," said Anna Gundlach, a puzzle fan and crossword constructor who lives in Portland, Oregon. "A lot of the distribution channels are able to be bypassed entirely."
The proliferation of independent crossword puzzles means a wider range of clues and answers and more provocative content. Puzzle editors at the New York Times reject puzzles if they decide a clue or answer is too obscure. Gundlach said the paper passed on one of hers because it referenced Bell Biv DeVoe.
"The American Values Club, which I've done a crossword for recently, has a more Gen X, millennial bent to it," she said. "Fresher clues, not afraid to swear or talk about sex."
Gundlach has had a nearly lifelong puzzle obsession. For Howard Barkin, a love of crosswords came late. He started solving them in his early 30s during lunch breaks to get his mind off work. Now he's 45 and a legit crossword puzzle champion. Barkin, who lives in Somerset County, finished first in the 2016 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament in Stamford, Connecticut.
Shortz is the director for the contest, which pits the best crossword solvers against one another in seven games over the course of a weekend, culminating in a final round for the three finalists. Barkin's tournament victory came after solving the last puzzle in 7 minutes, 49 seconds.
The stress was high, Barkin said.
"Most people aren't used to solving a crossword with a timer counting down in a room full of 500 people," he said.
Barkin also constructs crosswords when he frees time between doing dishes and raising two young daughters. He said his favorite to solve involve "extremely evil" tricks.
"A puzzle that breaks the rules, but for a good reason," he said. "A puzzle where you have to write a Greek letter into a square or something. It's a good kind of torture."
'Wow us' Even with a host of alternatives, the gold standard crossword remains the one The New York Times publishes.
"It's capital T, capital C: The Crossword," Gundlach said. "When people talk about 'the Sunday crossword' or 'the Friday crossword,' that's generally assumed to be the New York Times crossword."
Crossword fans use the hashtag #NYTXW on Twitter to brag about their finish times and offer their often-harsh criticism of that day's puzzle. The Dec. 12 crossword elicited reviews like "Ugh. So Bible heavy and then that twist? No." and "Ok #NYTXW sorry I don't know the ATOMIC NUMBER of NEODYMIUM?!?!"
The paper's associate puzzles editor, Sam Ezersky, doesn't take that kind of criticism personally. His Facebook banner photo is a foul-mouthed pan of one of his crossword puzzles.
"It's an obsessive culture," Ezersky said. "I get being so passionate about something like this."
Ezersky grew up in a Washington, D.C., suburb as a puzzles fanatic and sold his first crossword puzzle to the Los Angeles Times when he was 16 years old. He's 24 now, lives in Hoboken, New Jersey, and spends his days sifting through some of the roughly 600 crossword puzzle submissions the New York Times receives monthly (via snail mail only). Some he turns down with nothing more than a glance. Either the grid is an odd pattern, or the words are meh.
"We're just looking for fresh things that really capture our attention," he said. "These days we really need the puzzles to wow us."
Ezersky does not construct puzzles as much as he used to, but he snagged a dream assignment this year, creating the annual "super mega" crossword that ran Dec. 15 in the New York Times' special puzzles section. It was a massive undertaking: a 50x50-square grid with 708 answers. It's so big the clues are printed on a separate page. Ezersky estimates it took hundreds of hours to construct. Still, he would have begged to do it if necessary.
"I know there were other constructors that declined because it's a such a Herculean task," he said. "If I could have been totally no filter and not cared about professionality, I would have been like, 'Please, please, please, please, please.'"
An Ezersky crossword from August shows how his mind works when he puzzles out a puzzle. He began with the across answer at the bottom left, where he placed "tech-savvy." He then stacked "heist film" right on top, giving himself the unenviable challenge of finding a down answer that ends with "lv." He did: "capital V."
Once the grid is done, he dreams up clues. He clued "tech-savvy" with "E-sharp?" – that question mark is crossword-ese indicating there's a joke or pun involved – and asked readers to get to "capital V" with the clue "Symbol for 54-down." The answer was "volts."
Constructing crossword puzzles can be agonizing, Ezersky said, but he wouldn't want any other job.
"My mantra to myself is I'm just getting started," he said. "I'm just humbled and grateful to be doing what I'm doing."
Email: mcdonaldt@northjersey.com Twitter: @terrencemcd
"They have never been as popular, with the possible exception of 1924. Now crosswords are more up to date, they're livelier, they feel more modern."
Will Shortz
New York Times crossword puzzle editor
Howard Barkin, a regular finalist and the 2016 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament champion, works on a puzzle.
Anne-Marie Caruso/usa today network - New Jersey
